verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:1
verses.text: History of Theodoret  Book I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:2
verses.text: Prologue—Design of the History.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:3
verses.text: When artists paint on panels and on walls the events of ancient history, they alike delight the eye, and keep bright for many a year the memory of the past.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:4
verses.text: Historians substitute books for panels, bright description for pigments, and thus render the memory of past events both stronger and more permanent, for the painter's art is ruined by time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:5
verses.text: For this reason I too shall attempt to record in writing events in ecclesiastical history hitherto omitted, deeming it indeed not right to look on without an effort while oblivion robs noble deeds and useful stories of their due fame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:6
verses.text: For this cause too I have been frequently urged by friends to undertake this work.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:7
verses.text: But when I compare my own powers with the magnitude of the undertaking, I shrink from attempting it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:8
verses.text: Trusting, however, in the bounty of the Giver of all good, I enter upon a task beyond my own strength.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:9
verses.text: Eusebius of Palestine has written a history of the Church from the time of the holy Apostles to the reign of Constantine, the prince beloved of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:10
verses.text: I shall begin my history from the period at which his terminates.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:11
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:12
verses.text: —Origin of the Arian Heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:13
verses.text: After the overthrow of the wicked and impious tyrants, Maxentius, Maximinus, and Licinius, the surge which those destroyers, like hurricanes, had roused was hushed to sleep; the whirlwinds were checked, and the Church henceforward began to enjoy a settled calm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:14
verses.text: This was established for her by Constantine, a prince deserving of all praise, whose calling, like that of the divine Apostle, was not of men, nor by man, but from heaven.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:15
verses.text: He enacted laws prohibiting sacrifices to idols, and commanding churches to be erected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:16
verses.text: He appointed Christians to be governors of the provinces, ordering honour to be shown to the priests, and threatening with death those who dared to insult them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:17
verses.text: By some the churches which had been destroyed were rebuilt; others erected new ones still more spacious and magnificent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:18
verses.text: Hence, for us, all was joy and gladness, while our enemies were overwhelmed with gloom and despair.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:19
verses.text: The temples of the idols were closed; but frequent assemblies were held, and festivals celebrated, in the churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:20
verses.text: But the devil, full of all envy and wickedness, the destroyer of mankind, unable to bear the sight of the Church sailing on with favourable winds, stirred up plans of evil counsel, eager to sink the vessel steered by the Creator and Lord of the Universe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:21
verses.text: When he began to perceive that the error of the Greeks had been made manifest, that the various tricks of the demons had been detected, and that the greater number of men worshipped the Creator, instead of adoring, as heretofore, the creature, he did not dare to declare open war against our God and Saviour; but having found some who, though dignified with the name of Christians, were yet slaves to ambition and vainglory, he made them fit instruments for the execution of his designs, and by their means drew others back into their old error, not indeed by the former method of setting up the worship of the creature, but by bringing it about that the Creator and Maker of all should be reduced to a level with the creature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:22
verses.text: I shall now proceed to relate where and by what means he sowed these tares.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:23
verses.text: Alexandria is an immense and populous city, charged with the leadership not only of Egypt, but also of the adjacent countries, the Thebaid and Libya.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:24
verses.text: After Peter, the victorious champion of the faith, had, during the sway of the aforesaid impious tyrants, obtained the crown of martyrdom, the Church in Alexandria was ruled for a short time by Achillas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:25
verses.text: He was succeeded by Alexander, who proved himself a noble defender of the doctrines of the gospel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:26
verses.text: At that time, Arius, who had been enrolled in the list of the presbytery, and entrusted with the exposition of the Holy Scriptures, fell a prey to the assaults of jealousy, when he saw that the helm of the high priesthood was committed to Alexander.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:27
verses.text: Stung by this passion, he sought opportunities for dispute and contention; and, although he perceived that Alexander's irreproachable conduct forbade his bringing any charges against him, envy would not allow him to rest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:28
verses.text: In him the enemy of the truth found an instrument whereby to stir and agitate the angry waters of the Church, and persuaded him to oppose the apostolical doctrine of Alexander.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:29
verses.text: While the Patriarch, in obedience to the Holy Scriptures, taught that the Son is of equal dignity with the Father, and of the same substance with God who begat Him, Arius, in direct opposition to the truth, affirmed that the Son of God is merely a creature or created being, adding the famous dictum, "There once was a time when He was not;" with other opinions which may be learned from his own writings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:30
verses.text: He taught these false doctrines perseveringly, not only in the church, but also in general meetings and assemblies; and he even went from house to house, endeavouring to make men the slaves of his error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 1:31
verses.text: Alexander, who was strongly attached to the doctrines of the Apostles, at first tried by exhortations and counsels to convince him of his error; but when he saw him playing the madman and making public declaration of his impiety, he deposed him from the order of the presbytery, for he heard the law of God loudly declaring, "If thy right eye offend thee, pluck it out, and cast it from thee".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:2
verses.text: —List of the Principal Bishops  Of the church of Rome at this period Silvester held the reins.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:3
verses.text: His predecessor in the see was Miltiades, the successor of that Marcellinus who had so nobly distinguished himself during the persecution.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:4
verses.text: In Antioch, after the death of Tyrannus, when peace began to be restored to the churches, Vitalis received the chief authority, and restored the church in the "Palaea" which had been destroyed by the tyrants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:5
verses.text: He was succeeded by Philogonius, who completed all that was wanting in the work of restoration: he had, during the time of Licinius, signalised himself by his zeal for religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:6
verses.text: After the administration of Hermon, the government of the church in Jerusalem was committed to Macarius, a man whose character was equal to his name, and whose mind was adorned by every kind of virtue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:7
verses.text: At this same period also, Alexander, illustrious for his apostolical gifts, governed the church of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:8
verses.text: It was at this time that Alexander, bishop of Alexandria, perceiving that Arius, enslaved by the lust of power, was assembling those who had been taken captive by his blasphemous doctrines, and was holding private meetings, communicated an account of his heresy by letter to the rulers of the principal churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:9
verses.text: That the authenticity of my history may not be suspected, I shall now insert in my narrative the letter which he wrote to his namesake, containing, as it does, a clear account of all the facts I have mentioned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:10
verses.text: I shall also subjoin the letter of Arius, together with the other letters which are necessary to the completeness of this narrative, that they may at once testify to the truth of my work, and make the course of events more clear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 2:11
verses.text: The following letter was written by Alexander of Alexandria, to the bishop of the same name as himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:2
verses.text: —The Epistle of Alexander, Bishop of Alexandria to Alexander, Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:3
verses.text: "To his most revered and likeminded brother Alexander, Alexander sendeth greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:4
verses.text: "Impelled by avarice and ambition, evil-minded persons have ever plotted against the wellbeing of the most important dioceses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:5
verses.text: Under various pretexts, they attack the religion of the Church; and, being maddened by the devil, who works in them, they start aside from all piety according to their own pleasure, and trample under foot the fear of the judgment of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:6
verses.text: Suffering as I do from them myself, I deem it necessary to inform your piety, that you may be on your guard against them, lest they or any of their party should presume to enter your diocese (for these cheats are skilful in deception), or should circulate false and specious letters, calculated to delude one who has devoted himself to the simple and undefiled faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:7
verses.text: "Arius and Achillas have lately formed a conspiracy, and, emulating the ambition of Colluthus, have gone far beyond him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:8
verses.text: He indeed sought to find a pretext for his own pernicious line of action in the charges he brought against them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:9
verses.text: But they, beholding his making a trade of Christ for lucre, refused to remain any longer in subjection to the Church; but built for themselves caves, like robbers, and now constantly assemble in them, and day and night ply slanders there against Christ and against us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:10
verses.text: They revile every godly apostolical doctrine, and in Jewish fashion have organized a gang to fight against Christ, denying His divinity, and declaring Him to be on a level with other men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:11
verses.text: They pick out every passage which refers to the dispensation of salvation, and to His humiliation for our sake; they endeavour to collect from them their own impious assertion, while they evade all those which declare His eternal divinity, and the unceasing glory which He possesses with the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:12
verses.text: They maintain the ungodly doctrine entertained by the Greeks and the Jews concerning Jesus Christ; and thus, by every means in their power, hunt for their applause.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:13
verses.text: Everything which outsiders ridicule in us they officiously practise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:14
verses.text: They daily excite persecutions and seditions against us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:15
verses.text: On the one hand they bring accusations against us before the courts, suborning as witnesses certain unprincipled women whom they have seduced into error.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:16
verses.text: On the other they dishonour Christianity by permitting their young women to ramble about the streets.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:17
verses.text: Nay, they have had the audacity to rend the seamless garment of Christ, which the soldiers dared not divide.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:18
verses.text: "When these actions, in keeping with their course of life, and the impious enterprise which had been long concealed, became tardily known to us, we unanimously ejected them from the Church which worships the divinity of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:19
verses.text: They then ran hither and thither to form cabals against us, even addressing themselves to our fellow-ministers who were of one mind with us, under the pretence of seeking peace and unity with them, but in truth endeavouring by means of fair words, to sweep some among them away into their own disease.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:20
verses.text: They ask them to write a wordy letter, and then read the contents to those whom they have deceived, in order that they may not retract, but be confirmed in their impiety, by finding that bishops agree with and support their views.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:21
verses.text: They make no acknowledgment of the evil doctrines and practices for which they have been expelled by us, but they either impart them without comment, or carry on the deception by fallacies and forgeries.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:22
verses.text: Thus concealing their destructive doctrine by persuasive and meanly truckling language, they catch the unwary, and lose no opportunity of calumniating our religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:23
verses.text: Hence it arises that several have been led to sign their letter, and to receive them into communion, a proceeding on the part of our fellow-ministers which I consider highly reprehensible; for they thus not only disobey the apostolical rule, but even help to inflame their diabolical action against Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:24
verses.text: It is on this account, beloved brethren, that without delay I have stirred myself up to inform you of the unbelief of certain persons who say that "There was a time when the Son of God was not;" and "He who previously had no existence subsequently came into existence; and when at some time He came into existence He became such as every other man is".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:25
verses.text: God, they say, created all things out of that which was non-existent, and they include in the number of creatures, both rational and irrational, even the Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:26
verses.text: Consistently with this doctrine they, as a necessary consequence, affirm that He is by nature liable to change, and capable both of virtue and of vice, and thus, by their hypothesis of his having been created out of that which was non-existent, they overthrow the testimony of the Divine Scriptures, which declare the immutability of the Word and the Divinity of the Wisdom of the Word, which Word and Wisdom is Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:27
verses.text: 'We are also able,' say these accursed wretches, 'to become like Him, the sons of God; for it is written,—I have nourished and brought up children.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:28
verses.text: ' When the continuation of this text is brought before them, which is, 'and they have rebelled against Me,' and it is objected that these words are inconsistent with the Saviour's nature, which is immutable, they throw aside all reverence, and affirm that God foreknew and foresaw that His Son would not rebel against Him, and that He therefore chose Him in preference to all others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:29
verses.text: They likewise assert that He was not chosen because He had by nature any thing superior to the other sons of God; for no man, say they, is son of God by nature, nor has any peculiar relation to Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:30
verses.text: He was chosen, they allege, because, though mutable by nature, His painstaking character suffered no deterioration.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:31
verses.text: As though, forsooth, even if a Paul and a Peter made like endeavours, their sonship would in no respects differ from His.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:32
verses.text: "To establish this insane doctrine they insult the Scriptures, and bring forward what is said in the Psalms of Christ, 'Thou hast loved righteousness and hated iniquity, therefore thy God hath anointed thee with the oil of gladness above thy fellows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:33
verses.text: ' Now that the Son of God was not created out of the non-existent, and that there never was a time in which He was not, is expressly taught by John the Evangelist, who speaks of Him as 'the only begotten Son which is in the bosom of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:34
verses.text: ' This divine teacher desired to show that the Father and the Son are inseparable; and, therefore, he said, 'that the Son is in the bosom of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:35
verses.text: ' Moreover, the same John affirms that the Word of God is not classed among things created out of the non-existent, for, he says that 'all things were made by Him,' and he also declares His individual personality in the following words: 'In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:36
verses.text: …All things were made by Him, and without Him was not any thing made that was made.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:37
verses.text: ' If, then, all things were made by Him, how is it that He who thus bestowed existence on all, could at any period have had no existence himself? The Word, the creating power, can in no way be defined as of the same nature as the things created, if indeed He was in the beginning, and all things were made by Him, and were called by Him out of the non-existent into being.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:38
verses.text: 'That which is' must be of an opposite nature to, and essentially different from, things created out of the non-existent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:39
verses.text: This shows, likewise, that there is no separation between the Father and the Son, and that the idea of separation cannot even be conceived by the mind; while the fact that the world was created out of the non-existent involves a later and fresh genesis of its essential nature, all things having been endowed with such an origin of existence by the Father through the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:40
verses.text: John, the most pious apostle, perceiving that the word 'was' applied to the Word of God was far beyond and above the intelligence of created beings, did not presume to speak of His generation or creation, nor yet dared to name the Maker and the creature in equivalent syllables.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:41
verses.text: Not that the Son of God is unbegotten, for the Father alone is unbegotten; but that the ineffable personality of the only-begotten God is beyond the keenest conception of the evangelists and perhaps even of angels.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:42
verses.text: Therefore, I do not think men ought to be considered pious who presume to investigate this subject, in disobedience to the injunction, 'Seek not what is too difficult for thee, neither enquire into what is too high for thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:43
verses.text: ' For if the knowledge of many other things incomparably inferior is beyond the capacity of the human mind, and cannot therefore be attained, as has been said by Paul, 'Eye hath not seen, nor ear heard, neither have entered into the heart of man, the things which God hath prepared for them that love Him,' and as God also said to Abraham, that the stars could not be numbered by him; and it is likewise said, 'Who shall number the grains of sand by the sea-shore, or the drops of rain?' how then can any one but a madman presume to enquire into the nature of the Word of God? It is said by the Spirit of prophecy, 'Who shall declare His generation?' And, therefore, our Saviour in His kindness to those men who were the pillars of the whole world, desiring to relieve them of the burden of striving after this knowledge, told them that it was beyond their natural comprehension, and that the Father alone could discern this most divine mystery; 'No man,' said He, 'knoweth the Son but the Father, and no man knoweth the Father save the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:44
verses.text: ' It was, I think, concerning this same subject that the Father said, 'My secret is for Me and for Mine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:45
verses.text: '  "But the insane folly of imagining that the Son of God came into being out of that which had no being, and that His sending forth took place in time, is plain from the words 'which had no being,' although the foolish are incapable of perceiving the folly of their own utterances.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:46
verses.text: For the phrase 'He was not' must either have reference to time, or to some interval in the ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:47
verses.text: If then it be true that all things were made by Him, it is evident that every age, time, all intervals of time, and that 'when' in which 'was not' has its place, were made by Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:48
verses.text: And is it not absurd to say that there was a time when He who created all time, and ages, and seasons, with which the 'was not' is confused, was not? For it would be the height of ignorance, and contrary indeed to all reason, to affirm that the cause of any created thing can be posterior to that caused by it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:49
verses.text: The interval during which they say the Son was still unbegotten of the Father was, according to their opinion, prior to the wisdom of God, by whom all things were created.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:50
verses.text: They thus contradict the Scripture which declares Him to be 'the firstborn of every creature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:51
verses.text: ' In consonance with this doctrine, Paul with his usual mighty voice cries concerning Him; 'whom He hath appointed heir of all things, by whom also He made the worlds ' 'For by Him were all things created that are in heaven, and that are in earth, visible and invisible, whether they be thrones, or dominions, or principalities, or powers: all things were created by Him and for Him: and He is before all things ' Since the hypothesis implied in the phrase 'out of the non-existent' is manifestly impious, it follows that the Father is always Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:52
verses.text: And He is Father from the continual presence of the Son, on account of whom He is called Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:53
verses.text: And the Son being ever present with Him, the Father is ever perfect, wanting in no good thing, for He did not beget His only Son in time, or in any interval of time, nor out of that which had no previous existence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:54
verses.text: "Is it not then impious to say that there was a time when the wisdom of God was not? Who saith, 'I was by Him as one brought up with Him: I was daily His delight?' Or that once the power of God was not, or His Word, or anything else by which the Son is known, or the Father designated, defective? To assert that the brightness of the Father's glory 'once did not exist,' destroys also the original light of which it is the brightness; and if there ever was a time in which the image of God was not, it is plain that He Whose image He is, is not always: nay, by the non-existence of the express image of God's Person, He also is taken away of whom this is ever the express image.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:55
verses.text: Hence it may be seen, that the Sonship of our Saviour has not even anything in common with the sonship of men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:56
verses.text: For just as it has been shown that the nature of His existence cannot be expressed by language, and infinitely surpasses in excellence all things to which He has given being, so His Sonship, naturally partaking in His paternal Divinity, is unspeakably different from the sonship of those who, by His appointment, have been adopted as sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:57
verses.text: He is by nature immutable, perfect, and all-sufficient, whereas men are liable to change, and need His help.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:58
verses.text: What further advance can be made by the wisdom of God? What can the Very Truth, or God the Word, add to itself? How can the Life or the True Light in any way be bettered? And is it not still more contrary to nature to suppose that wisdom can be susceptible of folly? that the power of God can be united with weakness? that reason itself can be dimmed by unreasonableness, or that darkness can be mixed with the true light? Does not the Apostle say, 'What communion hath light with darkness? and what concord hath Christ with Belial?' and Solomon, that 'the way of a serpent upon a rock ' was 'too wonderful' for the human mind to comprehend, which 'rock,' according to St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:59
verses.text: Paul, is Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:60
verses.text: Men and angels, however, who are His creatures, have received His blessing, enabling them to exercise themselves in virtue and in obedience to His commands, that thus they may avoid sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:61
verses.text: And it is on this account that our Lord being by nature the Son of the Father, is worshipped by all; and they who have put off the spirit of bondage, and by brave deeds and advance in virtue have received the spirit of adoption through the kindness of Him Who is the Son of God by nature, by adoption also become sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:62
verses.text: "His true, peculiar, natural, and special Sonship was declared by Paul, who, speaking of God, says, that 'He spared not His own Son, but delivered Him up for us,' who are not by nature His sons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:63
verses.text: It was to distinguish Him from those who are not 'His own,' that he called Him 'His own son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:64
verses.text: ' It is also written in the Gospel, 'This is My beloved Son in whom I am well pleased;' and in the Psalms the Saviour says, 'The Lord said unto Me, Thou art My Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:65
verses.text: ' By proclaiming natural sonship He shows that there are no other natural sons besides Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:66
verses.text: "And do not these words, I begot thee 'from the womb before the morning,' plainly show the natural sonship of the paternal birth of One whose lot it is, not from diligence of conduct, or exercise in moral progress, but by individuality of nature? Hence it ensues that the filiation of the only-begotten Son of the Father is incapable of fall; while the adoption of reasonable beings who are not His sons by nature, but merely on account of fitness of character, and by the bounty of God, may fall away, as it is written in the word, 'The sons of God saw the daughters of men, and took them as wives,' and so forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:67
verses.text: And God, speaking by Isaiah, said, 'I have nourished and brought up children, and they have rebelled against Me.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:68
verses.text: '  "I have many things to say, beloved, but because I fear that I shall cause weariness by further admonishing teachers who are of one mind with myself, I pass them by.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:69
verses.text: You, having been taught of God, are not ignorant that the teaching at variance with the religion of the Church which has just arisen, is the same as that propagated by Ebion and Artemas, and rivals that of Paul of Samosata, bishop of Antioch, who was excommunicated by a council of all the bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:70
verses.text: Lucianus, his successor, withdrew himself from communion with these bishops during a period of many years.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:71
verses.text: "And now amongst us there have sprung up, 'out of the non-existent' men who have greedily sucked down the dregs of this impiety, offsets of the same stock: I mean Arius and Achillas, and all their gang of rogues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:72
verses.text: Three bishops of Syria, appointed no one knows how, by consenting to them, fire them to more fatal heat.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:73
verses.text: I refer their sentence to your decision.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:74
verses.text: Retaining in their memory all that they can collect concerning the suffering, humiliation, emptying of Himself, and so-called poverty, and everything of which the Saviour for our sake accepted the acquired name, they bring forward those passages to disprove His eternal existence and divinity, while they forget all those which declare His glory and nobility and abiding with the Father; as for instance, 'I and My father are one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:75
verses.text: ' In these words the Lord does not proclaim Himself to be the Father, neither does He represent two natures as one; but that the essence of the Son of the Father preserves accurately the likeness of the Father, His nature taking off the impress of likeness to Him in all things, being the exact image of the Father and the express stamp of the prototype.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:76
verses.text: When, therefore, Philip, desirous of seeing the Father, said to Him, 'Lord, show us the Father,' the Lord with abundant plainness said to him, 'He that hath seen Me hath seen the Father,' as though the Father were beheld in the spotless and living mirror of His image.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:77
verses.text: The same idea is conveyed in the Psalms, where the saints say, 'In Thy light we shall see light.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:78
verses.text: ' It is on this account that 'he who honoureth the Son, honoureth the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:79
verses.text: ' And rightly, for every impious word which men dare to utter against the Son is spoken also against the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:80
verses.text: "After this no one can wonder at the false calumnies which I am about to detail, my beloved brethren, propagated by them against me, and against our most religious people.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:81
verses.text: They not only set their battle in array against the divinity of Christ, but ungratefully insult us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:82
verses.text: They think it beneath them to be compared with any of those of old time, nor do they endure to be put on a par with the teachers we have been conversant with from childhood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:83
verses.text: They will not admit that any of our fellow-ministers anywhere possess even mediocrity of intelligence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:84
verses.text: They say that they themselves alone are the wise and the poor, and discoverers of doctrines, and to them alone have been revealed those truths which, say they, have never entered the mind of any other individuals under the sun.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:85
verses.text: O what wicked arrogance! O what excessive folly! What false boasting, joined with madness and Satanic pride, has hardened their impious hearts! They are not ashamed to oppose the godly clearness of the ancient scriptures, nor yet does the unanimous piety of all our fellow-ministers concerning Christ blunt their audacity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:86
verses.text: Even devils will not suffer impiety like this; for even they refrain from speaking blasphemy against the Son of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:87
verses.text: "These then are the questions I have to raise, according to the ability I possess, with those who from their rude resources throw dust on the Christ, and try to slander our reverence for Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:88
verses.text: These inventors of silly tales assert that we, who reject their impious and unscriptural blasphemy concerning the creation of Christ from the non-existent, teach that there are two unbegotten Beings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:89
verses.text: For these ill-instructed men contend that one of these alternatives must hold; either He must be believed to have come out of the non-existent, or there are two unbegotten Beings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:90
verses.text: In their ignorance and want of practice in theology they do not realize how vast must be the distance between the Father who is uncreate, and the creatures, whether rational or irrational, which He created out of the non-existent; and that the only-begotten nature of Him Who is the Word of God, by Whom the Father created the universe out of the non-existent, standing, as it were, in the middle between the two, was begotten of the self-existent Father, as the Lord Himself testified when He said, 'Every one that loveth the Father, loveth also the Son that is begotten of Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:91
verses.text: '  "We believe, as is taught by the apostolical Church, in an only unbegotten Father, Who of His being hath no cause, immutable and invariable, and Who subsists always in one state of being, admitting neither of progression nor of diminution; Who gave the law, and the prophets, and the gospel; of patriarchs and apostles, and of all saints, Lord: and in one Lord Jesus Christ, the only-begotten Son of God, begotten not out of that which is not, but of the Father, Who is; yet not after the manner of material bodies, by severance or emanation, as Sabellius and Valentinus taught; but in an inexpressible and inexplicable manner, according to the saying which we quoted above, 'Who shall declare His generation?' since no mortal intellect can comprehend the nature of His Person, as the Father Himself cannot be comprehended, because the nature of reasonable beings is unable to grasp the manner in which He was begotten of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:92
verses.text: "But those who are led by the Spirit of truth have no need to learn these things of me, for the words long since spoken by the Saviour yet sound in our ears, 'No one knoweth who the Father is but the Son, and no one knoweth who the Son is but the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:93
verses.text: ' We have learnt that the Son is immutable and unchangeable, all-sufficient and perfect, like the Father, lacking only His "unbegotten".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:94
verses.text: He is the exact and precisely similar image of His Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:95
verses.text: For it is clear that the image fully contains everything by which the greater likeness exists, as the Lord taught us when He said, 'My Father is greater than I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:96
verses.text: ' And in accordance with this we believe that the Son always existed of the Father; for he is the brightness of His glory, and the express image of His Father's Person".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:97
verses.text: But let no one be led by the word 'always' to imagine that the Son is unbegotten, as is thought by some who have their intellects blinded: for to say that He was, that He has always been, and that before all ages, is not to say that He is unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:98
verses.text: "The mind of man could not possibly invent a term expressive of what is meant by being unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:99
verses.text: I believe that you are of this opinion; and, indeed, I feel confident in your orthodox view that none of these terms in any way signify the unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:100
verses.text: For all the terms appear to signify merely the extension of time, and are not adequate to express the divinity and, as it were, the primaeval being of the only-begotten Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:101
verses.text: They were used by the holy men who earnestly endeavoured to clear up the mystery, and who asked pardon from those who heard them, with a reasonable excuse for their failure, by saying 'as far as our comprehension has reached.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:102
verses.text: ' But if those who allege that what was 'known in part' has been 'done away' for them, expect from human lips anything beyond human powers, it is plain that the terms 'was,' and 'ever,' and 'before all ages,' fall far short of this expectation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:103
verses.text: But whatever they may mean, it is not the same as 'the unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:104
verses.text: ' Therefore His own individual dignity must be reserved to the Father as the Unbegotten One, no one being called the cause of His existence: to the Son likewise must be given the honour which befits Him, there being to Him a generation from the Father which has no beginning; we must render Him worship, as we have already said, only piously and religiously ascribing to Him the 'was' and the 'ever,' and the 'before all ages;' not however rejecting His divinity, but ascribing to Him a perfect likeness in all things to His Father, while at the same time we ascribe to the Father alone His own proper glory of 'the unbegotten,' even as the Saviour Himself says, 'My Father is greater than I.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:105
verses.text: '  "And in addition to this pious belief respecting the Father and the Son, we confess as the Sacred Scriptures teach us, one Holy Ghost, who moved the saints of the Old Testament, and the divine teachers of that which is called the New.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:106
verses.text: We believe in one only Catholic Church, the apostolical, which cannot be destroyed even though all the world were to take counsel to fight against it, and which gains the victory over all the impious attacks of the heterodox; for we are emboldened by the words of its Master, 'Be of good cheer, I have overcome the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:107
verses.text: ' After this, we receive the doctrine of the resurrection from the dead, of which Jesus Christ our Lord became the first-fruits; Who bore a Body, in truth, not in semblance, derived from Mary the mother of God; in the fulness of time sojourning among the race, for the remission of sins: who was crucified and died, yet for all this suffered no diminution of His Godhead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:108
verses.text: He rose from the dead, was taken into heaven, and sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:109
verses.text: "In this epistle I have only mentioned these things in part, deeming it, as I have said, wearisome to dwell minutely on each article, since they are well known to your pious diligence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:110
verses.text: These things we teach, these things we preach; these are the dogmas of the apostolic Church, for which we are ready to die, caring little for those who would force us to forswear them; for we will never relinquish our hope in them, though they should try to compel us by tortures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:111
verses.text: "Arius and Achillas, together with their fellow foes, have been expelled from the Church, because they have become aliens from our pious doctrine: according to the blessed Paul, who said, 'If any of you preach any other gospel than that which you have received, let him be accursed, even though he should pretend to be an angel from heaven, and 'But if any man teach otherwise, and consent not to wholesome words, even the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, and to the doctrine which is according to godliness, he is proud, knowing nothing,' and so forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:112
verses.text: Since, then, they have been condemned by the brotherhood, let none of you receive them, nor attend to what they say or write.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:113
verses.text: They are deceivers, and propagate lies, and they never adhere to the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:114
verses.text: They go about to different cities with no other intent than to deliver letters under the pretext of friendship and in the name of peace, and by hypocrisy and flattery to obtain other letters in return, in order to deceive a few 'silly women who are laden with sins.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:115
verses.text: ' I beseech you, beloved brethren, to avoid those who have thus dared to act against Christ, who have publicly held up the Christian religion to ridicule, and have eagerly sought to make a display before judicial tribunals, who have endeavoured to excite a persecution against us at a period of the most entire peace, and who have enervated the unspeakable mystery of the generation of Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:116
verses.text: Unite unanimously in opposition to them, as some of our fellow-ministers have already done, who, being filled with indignation, wrote to me against them, and signed our formulary.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:117
verses.text: "I have sent you these letters by my son Apion, the deacon; being those of (the ministers in) all Egypt and the Thebaid, also of those of Libya, and the Pentapolis, of Syria, Lycia, Pamphylia, Asia, Cappadocia, and in the other adjoining countries.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:118
verses.text: Whose example you likewise, I trust, will follow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:119
verses.text: Many kindly attempts have been made by me to gain back those who have been led astray, but no remedy has proved more efficacious in restoring the laity who have been deceived by them and leading them to repentance, than the manifestation of the union of our fellow-ministers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:120
verses.text: Salute one another, with the brotherhood that is with you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:121
verses.text: I pray that you may be strong in the Lord, my beloved, and that I may receive the fruit of your love to Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:122
verses.text: "The following are the name of those who have been anathematized as heretics: among the presbyters, Arius; among the deacons, Achillas, Euzoius, Aïthales, Lucius, Sarmates, Julius, Menas, another Arius, and Helladius".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:123
verses.text: Alexander wrote in the same strain to Philogonius, bishop of Antioch, to Eustathius, who then ruled the church of the Beroeans, and to all those who defended the doctrines of the Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:124
verses.text: But Arius could not endure to keep quiet, but wrote to all those whom he believed to agree with him in opinion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:125
verses.text: His letter to Eusebius, bishop of Nicomedia, is a clear proof that the divine Alexander wrote nothing that was false concerning him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 3:126
verses.text: I shall here insert his letter, in order that the names of those who were implicated in his impiety may become generally known.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:2
verses.text: —The Letter of Arius to Eusebius, Bishop of Nicomedia  "To his very dear lord, the man of God, the faithful and orthodox Eusebius, Arius, unjustly persecuted by Alexander the Pope, on account of that all-conquering truth of which you also are a champion, sendeth greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:3
verses.text: "Ammonius, my father, being about to depart for Nicomedia, I considered myself bound to salute you by him, and withal to inform that natural affection which you bear towards the brethren for the sake of God and His Christ, that the bishop greatly wastes and persecutes us, and leaves no stone unturned against us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:4
verses.text: He has driven us out of the city as atheists, because we do not concur in what he publicly preaches, namely, God always, the Son always; as the Father so the Son; the Son co-exists unbegotten with God; He is everlasting; neither by thought nor by any interval does God precede the Son; always God, always Son; he is begotten of the unbegotten; the Son is of God Himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:5
verses.text: Eusebius, your brother bishop of Caesarea, Theodotus, Paulinus, Athanasius, Gregorius, Aetius, and all the bishops of the East, have been condemned because they say that God had an existence prior to that of His Son; except Philogonius, Hellanicus, and Macarius, who are unlearned men, and who have embraced heretical opinions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:6
verses.text: Some of them say that the Son is an eructation, others that He is a production, others that He is also unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:7
verses.text: These are impieties to which we cannot listen, even though the heretics threaten us with a thousand deaths.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:8
verses.text: But we say and believe, and have taught, and do teach, that the Son is not unbegotten, nor in any way part of the unbegotten; and that He does not derive His subsistence from any matter; but that by His own will and counsel He has subsisted before time, and before ages, as perfect God, only begotten and unchangeable, and that before He was begotten, or created, or purposed, or established, He was not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:9
verses.text: For He was not unbegotten.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:10
verses.text: We are persecuted, because we say that the Son has a beginning, but that God is without beginning.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:11
verses.text: This is the cause of our persecution, and likewise, because we say that He is of the non-existent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:12
verses.text: And this we say, because He is neither part of God, nor of any essential being.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:13
verses.text: For this are we persecuted; the rest you know.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:14
verses.text: I bid thee farewell in the Lord, remembering our afflictions, my fellow-Lucianist, and true Eusebius".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:15
verses.text: Of those whose names are mentioned in this letter, Eusebius was bishop of Caesarea, Theodotus of Laodicea, Paulinus of Tyre, Athanasius of Anazarbus, Gregorius of Berytus, and Aetius of Lydda.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:16
verses.text: Lydda is now called Diospolis.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:17
verses.text: Arius prided himself on having these men of one mind with himself.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:18
verses.text: He names as his adversaries, Philogonius, bishop of Antioch, Hellanicus, of Tripolis, and Macarius, of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:19
verses.text: He spread calumnies against them because they said that the Son is eternal, existing before all ages, of equal honour and of the same substance with the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 4:20
verses.text: When Eusebius received the epistle, he too vomited forth his own impiety, and wrote to Paulinus, chief of the Tyrians, in the following words.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:2
verses.text: —The Letter of Eusebius, Bishop of Nicomedia, to Paulinus, Bishop of Tyre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:3
verses.text: "To my lord Paulinus, Eusebius sendeth greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:4
verses.text: "The zeal of my lord Eusebius in the cause of the truth, and likewise your silence concerning it, have not failed to reach our ears.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:5
verses.text: Accordingly, if, on the one hand, we rejoiced on account of the zeal of my lord Eusebius; on the other we are grieved at you, because even the silence of such a man appears like a defeat of our cause.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:6
verses.text: Hence, as it behoves not a wise man to be of a different opinion from others, and to be silent concerning the truth, stir up, I exhort you, within yourself the spirit of wisdom to write, and at length begin what may be profitable to yourself and to others, specially if you consent to write in accordance with Scripture, and tread in the tracks of its words and will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:7
verses.text: "We have never heard that there are two unbegotten beings, nor that one has been divided into two, nor have we learned or believed that it has ever undergone any change of a corporeal nature; but we affirm that the unbegotten is one and one also that which exists in truth by Him, yet was not made out of His substance, and does not at all participate in the nature or substance of the unbegotten, entirely distinct in nature and in power, and made after perfect likeness both of character and power to the maker.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:8
verses.text: We believe that the mode of His beginning not only cannot be expressed by words but even in thought, and is incomprehensible not only to man, but also to all beings superior to man.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:9
verses.text: These opinions we advance not as having derived them from our own imagination, but as having deduced them from Scripture, whence we learn that the Son was created, established, and begotten in the same substance and in the same immutable and inexpressible nature as the Maker; and so the Lord says, 'God created me in the beginning of His way; I was set up from everlasting; before the hills was I brought forth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:10
verses.text: '  "If He had been from Him or of Him, as a portion of Him, or by an emanation of His substance, it could not be said that He was created or established; and of this you, my lord, are certainly not ignorant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:11
verses.text: For that which is of the unbegotten could not be said to have been created or founded, either by Him or by another, since it is unbegotten from the beginning.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:12
verses.text: But if the fact of His being called the begotten gives any ground for the belief that, having come into being of the Father's substance, He also has from the Father likeness of nature, we reply that it is not of Him alone that the Scriptures have spoken as begotten, but that they also thus speak of those who are entirely dissimilar to Him by nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:13
verses.text: For of men it is said, 'I have begotten and brought up sons, and they have rebelled against me;' and in another place, 'Thou hast forsaken God who begat thee;' and again it is said, 'Who begat the drops of dew?' This expression does not imply that the dew partakes of the nature of God, but simply that all things were formed according to His will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:14
verses.text: There is, indeed, nothing which is of His substance, yet every thing which exists has been called into being by His will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:15
verses.text: He is God; and all things were made in His likeness, and in the future likeness of His Word, being created of His free will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:16
verses.text: All things were made by His means by God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:17
verses.text: All things are of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:18
verses.text: "When you have received my letter, and have revised it according to the knowledge and grace given you by God, I beg you will write as soon as possible to my lord Alexander.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:19
verses.text: I feel confident that if you would write to him, you would succeed in bringing him over to your opinion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:20
verses.text: Salute all the brethren in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:21
verses.text: May you, my lord, be preserved by the grace of God, and be led to pray for us".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:22
verses.text: It is thus that they wrote to each other, in order to furnish one another with weapons against the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:23
verses.text: And so when the blasphemous doctrine had been disseminated in the churches of Egypt and of the East, disputes and contentions arose in every city, and in every village, concerning theological dogmas.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:24
verses.text: The common people looked on, and became judges of what was said on either side, and some applauded one party, and some the other.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:25
verses.text: These were, indeed, scenes fit for the tragic stage, over which tears might have been shed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:26
verses.text: For it was not, as in bygone days, when the church was attacked by strangers and by enemies, but now natives of the same country, who dwelt under one roof, and sat down at one table, fought against each other not with spears, but with their tongues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 5:27
verses.text: And what was still more sad, they who thus took up arms against one another were members of one another, and belonged to one body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:2
verses.text: —General Council of Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:3
verses.text: The emperor, who possessed the most profound wisdom, having heard of these things, endeavoured, as a first step, to stop up their fountain-head.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:4
verses.text: He therefore despatched a messenger renowned for his ready wit to Alexandria with letters, in the endeavour to extinguish the dispute, and expecting to reconcile the disputants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:5
verses.text: But his hopes having been frustrated, he proceeded to summon the celebrated council of Nicaea; and pledged his word that the bishops and their officials should be furnished with asses, mules, and horses for their journey at the public expense.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:6
verses.text: When all those who were capable of enduring the fatigue of the journey had arrived at Nicaea, he went thither himself, with both the wish of seeing the multitude of bishops, and the yearning desire of maintaining unanimity amongst them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:7
verses.text: He at once arranged that all their wants should be liberally supplied.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:8
verses.text: Three hundred and eighteen bishops were assembled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:9
verses.text: The bishop of Rome, on account of his very advanced age, was absent, but he sent two presbyters to the council, with authority to agree to what was done.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:10
verses.text: At this period many individuals were richly endowed with apostolical gifts; and many, like the holy apostle, bore in their bodies the marks of the Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:11
verses.text: James, bishop of Antioch, a city of Mygdonia, which is called Nisibis by the Syrians and Assyrians, raised the dead and restored them to life, and performed many other wonders which it would be superfluous to mention again in detail in this history, as I have already given an account of them in my work, entitled "Philotheus".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:12
verses.text: Paul, bishop of Neo-Caesarea, a fortress situated on the banks of the Euphrates, had suffered from the frantic rage of Licinius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:13
verses.text: He had been deprived of the use of both hands by the application of a red-hot iron, by which the nerves which give motion to the muscles had been contracted and rendered dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:14
verses.text: Some had had the right eye dug out, others had lost the right arm.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:15
verses.text: Among these was Paphnutius of Egypt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:16
verses.text: In short, the Council looked like an assembled army of martyrs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:17
verses.text: Yet this holy and celebrated gathering was not entirely free from the element of opposition; for there were some, though so few as easily to be reckoned, of fair surface, like dangerous shallows, who really, though not openly, supported the blasphemy of Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:18
verses.text: When they were all assembled, the emperor ordered a great hall to be prepared for their accommodation in the palace, in which a sufficient number of benches and seats were placed; and having thus arranged that they should be treated with becoming dignity, he desired the bishops to enter in, and discuss the subjects proposed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:19
verses.text: The emperor, with a few attendants, was the last to enter the room; remarkable for his lofty stature, and worthy of admiration for personal beauty, and for the still more marvellous modesty which dwelt on his countenance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:20
verses.text: A low stool was placed for him in the middle of the assembly, upon which, however, he did not seat himself until he had asked the permission of the bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:21
verses.text: Then all the sacred assembly sat down around him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:22
verses.text: Then forthwith rose first the great Eustathius, bishop of Antioch, who, upon the translation of Philogonius, already referred to, to a better life, had been compelled reluctantly to become his successor by the unanimous suffrages of the bishops, priests, and of the Christ-loving laity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:23
verses.text: He crowned the emperor's head with the flowers of panegyric, and commended the diligent attention he had manifested in the regulation of ecclesiastical affairs.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:24
verses.text: The excellent emperor next exhorted the Bishops to unanimity and concord; he recalled to their remembrance the cruelty of the late tyrants, and reminded them of the honourable peace which God had, in his reign and by his means, accorded them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:25
verses.text: He pointed out how dreadful it was, aye, very dreadful, that at the very time when their enemies were destroyed, and when no one dared to oppose them, they should fall upon one another, and make their amused adversaries laugh, especially as they were debating about holy things, concerning which they had the written teaching of the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:26
verses.text: "For the gospels" (continued he), "the apostolical writings, and the oracles of the ancient prophets, clearly teach us what we ought to believe concerning the divine nature.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:27
verses.text: Let, then, all contentious disputation be discarded; and let us seek in the divinely-inspired word the solution of the questions at issue".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:28
verses.text: These and similar exhortations he, like an affectionate son, addressed to the bishops as to fathers, labouring to bring about their unanimity in the apostolical doctrines.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:29
verses.text: Most members of the synod, won over by his arguments, established concord among themselves, and embraced sound doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:30
verses.text: There were, however, a few, of whom mention has been already made, who opposed these doctrines, and sided with Arius; and amongst them were Menophantus, bishop of Ephesus, Patrophilus, bishop of Scythopolis, Theognis, bishop of Nicaea, and Narcissus, bishop of Neronias, which is a town of the second Cilicia, and is now called Irenopolis; also Theonas, bishop of Marmarica, and Secundus, bishop of Ptolemais in Egypt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:31
verses.text: They drew up a formulary of their faith, and presented it to the council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:32
verses.text: As soon as it was read it was torn to pieces, and was declared to be spurious and false.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:33
verses.text: So great was the uproar raised against them, and so many were the reproaches cast on them for having betrayed religion, that they all, with the exception of Secundus and Theonas, stood up and took the lead in publicly renouncing Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 6:34
verses.text: This impious man, having thus been expelled from the Church, a confession of faith which is received to this day was drawn up by unanimous consent; and, as soon as it was signed, the council was dissolved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:2
verses.text: —Confutation of Arianism deduced from the Writings of Eustathius and Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:3
verses.text: The above-named bishops, however, did not consent to it in sincerity, but only in appearance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:4
verses.text: This was afterwards shewn by their plotting against those who were foremost in zeal for religion, as well as by what these latter have written about them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:5
verses.text: For instance, Eustathius, the famous bishop of Antioch, who has been already mentioned, when explaining the text in the Proverbs, 'The Lord created me in the beginning of His way, before His works of old,' wrote against them, and refuted their blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:6
verses.text: "I will now proceed to relate how these different events occurred.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:7
verses.text: A general council was summoned at Nicaea, and about two hundred and seventy bishops were convened.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:8
verses.text: There were, however, so many assembled that I cannot state their exact number, neither, indeed, have I taken any great trouble to ascertain this point.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:9
verses.text: When they began to inquire into the nature of the faith, the formulary of Eusebius was brought forward, which contained undisguised evidence of his blasphemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:10
verses.text: The reading of it before all occasioned great grief to the audience, on account of its departure from the faith, while it inflicted irremediable shame on the writer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:11
verses.text: After the Eusebian gang had been clearly convicted, and the impious writing had been torn up in the sight of all, some amongst them by concert, under the pretence of preserving peace, imposed silence on all the ablest speakers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:12
verses.text: The Ariomaniacs, fearing lest they should be ejected from the Church by so numerous a council of bishops, sprang forward to anathematize and condemn the doctrines condemned, and unanimously signed the confession of faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:13
verses.text: Thus having retained possession of their episcopal seats through the most shameful deception, although they ought rather to have been degraded, they continue, sometimes secretly, and sometimes openly, to patronize the condemned doctrines, plotting against the truth by various arguments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:14
verses.text: Wholly bent upon establishing these plantations of tares, they shrink from the scrutiny of the intelligent, avoid the observant, and attack the preachers of godliness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:15
verses.text: But we do not believe that these atheists can ever thus overcome the Deity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:16
verses.text: For though they 'gird themselves' they 'shall be broken in pieces,' according to the solemn prophecy of Isaiah".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:17
verses.text: These are the words of the great Eustathius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:18
verses.text: Athanasius, his fellow combatant, the champion of the truth, who succeeded the celebrated Alexander in the episcopate, added the following, in a letter addressed to the Africans.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:19
verses.text: "The bishops convened in council being desirous of refuting the impious assertions invented by the Arians, that the Son was created out of that which was non-existent, that He is a creature and created being, that there was a period in which He was not, and that He is mutable by nature, and being all agreed in propounding the following declarations, which are in accordance with the holy Scriptures; namely, that the Son is by nature only-begotten of God, Word, Power, and sole Wisdom of the Father; that He is, as John said, 'the true God,' and, as Paul has written, 'the brightness of the glory, and the express image of the person of the Father,' the followers of Eusebius, drawn aside by their own vile doctrine, then began to say one to another, Let us agree, for we are also of God; 'There is but one God, by whom are all things; 'Old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new, and all things are of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:20
verses.text: ' They also dwelt particularly upon what is contained in 'The Shepherd:' 'Believe above all that there is one God, who created and fashioned all things, and making them to be out of that which is not.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:21
verses.text: '  "But the bishops saw through their evil design and impious artifice, and gave a clearer elucidation of the words 'of God,' and wrote, that the Son is of the substance of God; in order that while the creatures, which do not in any way derive their existence of or from themselves, are said to be of God, the Son alone is said to be of the substance of the Father; this being peculiar to the only-begotten Son, the true Word of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:22
verses.text: This is the reason why the bishops wrote, that He is of the substance of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:23
verses.text: "But when the Arians, who seemed few in number, were again interrogated by the Bishops as to whether they admitted 'that the Son is not a creature, but Power, and sole Wisdom, and eternal unchangeable Image of the Father; and that He is very God,' the Eusebians were noticed making signs to one another to shew that these declarations were equally applicable to us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:24
verses.text: For it is said, that we are 'the image and glory of God;' and 'for always we who live:' there are, also, they said, many powers; for it is written—'All the power of God went out of the land of Egypt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:25
verses.text: ' The canker-worm and the locust are said to be 'a great power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:26
verses.text: ' And elsewhere it is written, The God of powers is with us, the God of Jacob helper.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:27
verses.text: ' To which may be added that we are God's own not simply, but because the Son called us 'brethren.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:28
verses.text: ' The declaration that Christ is 'the true God' does not distress us, for, having come into being, He is true.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:29
verses.text: "Such was the corrupt opinion of the Arians; but on this the bishops, having detected their deceitfulness in this matter, collected from Scripture those passages which say of Christ that He is the glory, the fountain, the stream, and the express image of the person; and they quoted the following words: 'In thy light we shall see light;' and likewise, 'I and the Father are one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:30
verses.text: ' They then, with still greater clearness, briefly declared that the Son is of one substance with the Father; for this, indeed, is the signification of the passages which have been quoted.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:31
verses.text: The complaint of the Arians, that these precise words are not to be found in Scripture, is proved groundless by their own practice, for their own impious assertions are not taken from Scripture; for it is not written that the Son is of the non-existent, and that there was a time when He was not: and yet they complain of having been condemned by expressions which, though not actually in Scripture, are in accordance with true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:32
verses.text: They themselves, on the other hand, as though they had found their words on a dunghill, uttered things verily of earth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:33
verses.text: The bishops, on the contrary, did not find their expressions for themselves; but, received their testimony from the fathers, and wrote accordingly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:34
verses.text: Indeed, there were bishops of old time, nearly one hundred and thirty years ago, both of the great city of Rome and of our own city, who condemned those who asserted that the Son is a creature, and that He is not of one substance with the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:35
verses.text: Eusebius, the bishop of Caesarea, was acquainted with these facts; he, at one time, favoured the Arian heresy, but he afterwards signed the confession of faith of the Council of Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:36
verses.text: He wrote to the people of his diocese, maintaining that the word 'consubstantial' was 'used by illustrious bishops and learned writers as a term for expressing the divinity of the Father and of the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:37
verses.text: '"  So these men concealed their unsoundness through fear of the majority, and gave their assent to the decisions of the council, thus drawing upon themselves the condemnation of the prophet, for the God of all cries unto them, "This people honour Me with their lips, but in their hearts they are far from Me".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:38
verses.text: Theonas and Secundus, however, did not like to take this course, and were excommunicated by common consent as men who esteemed the Arian blasphemy above evangelical doctrine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 7:39
verses.text: The bishops then returned to the council, and drew up twenty laws to regulate the discipline of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:2
verses.text: —Facts relating to Meletius the Egyptian, from whom originated the Meletian Schism, which remains to this day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:3
verses.text: —Synodical Epistle respecting him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:4
verses.text: After Meletius had been ordained bishop, which was not long before the Arian controversy, he was convicted of certain crimes by the most holy Peter, bishop of Alexandria, who also received the crown of martyrdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:5
verses.text: After being deposed by Peter he did not acquiesce in his deposition, but filled the Thebaid and the adjacent part of Egypt with tumult and disturbance, and rebelled against the primacy of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:6
verses.text: A letter was written by the council to the Church of Alexandria, stating what had been decreed against his revolutionary practices.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:7
verses.text: It was as follows:—  Synodical Epistle.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:8
verses.text: "To the Church of Alexandria which, by the grace of God, is great and holy, and to the beloved brethren in Egypt, Libya, and Pentapolis, the bishops who have been convened to the great and holy council of Nicaea, send greeting in the Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:9
verses.text: "The great and holy council of Nicaea having been convened by the grace of God, and by the most religious emperor, Constantine, who summoned us from different provinces and cities, we judge it requisite that a letter be sent from the whole Holy Synod to inform you also what questions have been mooted and debated, and what has been decreed and established.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:10
