verses.text: "In the first place, the impious doctrines of Arius were investigated before our most religious emperor Constantine; and his impiety was unanimously anathematized, as well as the blasphemous language and views which he had propounded, alleging that the Son of God was out of what was not, that before He was begotten He was not, that there was a period in which He was not, and that He can, according to His own freewill, be capable either of virtue or of vice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:11
verses.text: The holy council anathematized all these assertions, and even refused so much as to listen to such impious and foolish opinions, and such blasphemous expressions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:12
verses.text: The final decision concerning him you already know, or will soon hear; but we will not mention it now, lest we should appear to trample upon a man who has already received the recompense due to his sins.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:13
verses.text: Such influence has his impiety obtained as to involve Theonas, bishop of Marmarica, and Secundus, bishop of Ptolemais, in his ruin, and they have shared his punishment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:14
verses.text: "But after Egypt had, by the grace of God, been delivered from these false and blasphemous opinions, and from persons who dared to raise discord and division among a hitherto peaceable people, there yet remained the question of the temerity of Meletius, and of those ordained by him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:15
verses.text: We now inform you, beloved brethren, of the decrees of the council on this subject.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:16
verses.text: It was decided by the holy council, that Meletius should be treated with clemency, though, strictly speaking, he was not worthy of even the least concession.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:17
verses.text: He was permitted to remain in his own city, but was divested of all power, whether of nomination or of ordination, neither was he to shew himself in any province or city for these purposes: but only to retain the bare name of his office.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:18
verses.text: Those who had received ordination at his hands were to submit to a more religious re-ordination; and were to be admitted to communion on the terms of retaining their ministry, but of ranking in every diocese and church below those who had been ordained before them by Alexander, our much-honoured fellow-minister.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:19
verses.text: Thus they would have no power of choosing or nominating others to the ministry, according to their pleasure, or indeed of doing anything with out the consent of the bishops of the Catholic and Apostolic Church, who are under Alexander.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:20
verses.text: But they who, by the grace of God, and in answer to your prayers, have been detected in no schism, and have continued spotless in the Catholic and Apostolic Church, are to have the power of electing, and of nominating men worthy of the clerical office, and are permitted to do whatsoever is in accordance with law and the authority of the Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:21
verses.text: If it should happen, that any of those now holding an office in the Church should die, then let these recently admitted be advanced to the honours of the deceased, provided only that they appear worthy, and that the people choose them, and that the election be confirmed and ratified by the catholic bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:22
verses.text: The same privilege has been conceded to all the others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:23
verses.text: With respect to Meletius, however, an exception has been made, both on account of his former insubordination, and of the rashness and impetuosity of his disposition; for if the least authority were accorded to him, he might abuse it by again exciting confusion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:24
verses.text: These are the chief points which relate to Egypt, and to the holy Church of Alexandria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:25
verses.text: Whatever other canons were made, or dogmas decreed, you will hear of them from Alexander, our most-honoured fellow-minister and brother, who will give you still more accurate information, because he himself directed, as well as participated in, every thing that took place.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:26
verses.text: "We also give you the good news that, according to your prayers, the celebration of the most holy paschal feast was unanimously rectified, so that our brethren of the East, who did not previously keep the festival at the same time as those of Rome, and as yourselves, and, indeed, all have done from the beginning, will henceforth celebrate it with you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:27
verses.text: Rejoice, then, in the success of our undertakings, and in the general peace and concord, and in the extirpation of every heresy, and receive with still greater honour and more fervent love, Alexander, our fellow-minister and your bishop, who imparted joy to us by his presence, and who, at a very advanced age, has undergone so much fatigue for the purpose of restoring peace among you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:28
verses.text: Pray for us all, that what has been rightly decreed may remain steadfast, through our Lord Jesus Christ, being done, as we trust, according to the good pleasure of God and the Father in the Holy Ghost, to whom be glory for ever and ever, Amen".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 8:29
verses.text: Notwithstanding the endeavours of that divine assembly of bishops to apply this medicine to the Meletian disease, vestiges of his infatuation remain even to this day; for there are in some districts bodies of monks who refuse to follow sound doctrine, and observe certain vain points of discipline, agreeing with the infatuated views of the Jews and the Samaritans.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:2
verses.text: —The Epistle of the Emperor Constantine, concerning the matters transacted at the Council, addressed to those Bishops who were not present.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:3
verses.text: The great emperor also wrote an account of the transactions of the council to those bishops who were unable to attend.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:4
verses.text: And I consider it worth while to insert this epistle in my work, as it clearly evidences the piety of the writer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:5
verses.text: "Constantinus Augustus to the Churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:6
verses.text: "Viewing the common public prosperity enjoyed at this moment, as the result of the great power of divine grace, I am desirous above all things that the blessed members of the Catholic Church should be preserved in one faith, in sincere love, and in one form of religion, towards Almighty God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:7
verses.text: But, since no firmer or more effective measure could be adopted to secure this end, than that of submitting everything relating to our most holy religion to the examination of all, or most of all, the bishops, I convened as many of them as possible, and took my seat among them as one of yourselves; for I would not deny that truth which is the source of my greatest joy, namely, that I am your fellow-servant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:8
verses.text: Every point obtained its due investigation, until the doctrine pleasing to the all-seeing God, and conducive to unity, was made clear, so that no room should remain for division or controversy concerning the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:9
verses.text: "The commemoration of the most sacred paschal feast being then debated, it was unanimously decided, that it would be well that it should be everywhere celebrated upon the same day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:10
verses.text: What can be more fair, or more seemly, than that that festival by which we have received the hope of immortality should be carefully celebrated by all, on plain grounds, with the same order and exactitude? It was, in the first place, declared improper to follow the custom of the Jews in the celebration of this holy festival, because, their hands having been stained with crime, the minds of these wretched men are necessarily blinded.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:11
verses.text: By rejecting their custom, we establish and hand down to succeeding ages one which is more reasonable, and which has been observed ever since the day of our Lord's sufferings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:12
verses.text: Let us, then, have nothing in common with the Jews, who are our adversaries.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:13
verses.text: For we have received from our Saviour another way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:14
verses.text: A better and more lawful line of conduct is inculcated by our holy religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:15
verses.text: Let us with one accord walk therein, my much-honoured brethren, studiously avoiding all contact with that evil way.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:16
verses.text: They boast that without their instructions we should be unable to commemorate the festival properly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:17
verses.text: This is the highest pitch of absurdity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:18
verses.text: For how can they entertain right views on any point who, after having compassed the death of the Lord, being out of their minds, are guided not by sound reason, but by an unrestrained passion, wherever their innate madness carries them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:19
verses.text: Hence it follows that they have so far lost sight of truth, wandering as far as possible from the correct revisal, that they celebrate a second Passover in the same year.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:20
verses.text: What motive can we have for following those who are thus confessedly unsound and in dire error? For we could never tolerate celebrating the Passover twice in one year.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:21
verses.text: But even if all these facts did not exist, your own sagacity would prompt you to watch with diligence and with prayer, lest your pure minds should appear to share in the customs of a people so utterly depraved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:22
verses.text: It must also be borne in mind, that upon so important a point as the celebration of a feast of such sanctity, discord is wrong.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:23
verses.text: One day has our Saviour set apart for a commemoration of our deliverance, namely, of His most holy Passion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:24
verses.text: One hath He wished His Catholic Church to be, whereof the members, though dispersed throughout the most various parts of the world, are yet nourished by one spirit, that is, by the divine will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:25
verses.text: Let your pious sagacity reflect how evil and improper it is, that days devoted by some to fasting, should be spent by others in convivial feasting; and that after the paschal feast, some are rejoicing in festivals and relaxations, while others give themselves up to the appointed fasts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:26
verses.text: That this impropriety should be rectified, and that all these diversities of commemoration should be resolved into one form, is the will of divine Providence, as I am convinced you will all perceive.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:27
verses.text: Therefore, this irregularity must be corrected, in order that we may no more have any thing in common with those parricides and the murderers of our Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:28
verses.text: An orderly and excellent form of commemoration is observed in all the churches of the western, of the southern, and of the northern parts of the world, and by some of the eastern; this form being universally commended, I engaged that you would be ready to adopt it likewise, and thus gladly accept the rule unanimously adopted in the city of Rome, throughout Italy, in all Africa, in Egypt, the Spains, the Gauls, the Britains, Libya, Greece, in the dioceses of Asia, and of Pontus, and in Cilicia, taking into your consideration not only that the churches of the places above-mentioned are greater in point of number, but also that it is most pious that all should unanimously agree in that course which accurate reasoning seems to demand, and which has no single point in common with the perjury of the Jews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:29
verses.text: "Briefly to summarize the whole of the preceding, the judgment of all is, that the holy Paschal feast should be held on one and the same day; for, in so holy a matter, it is not becoming that any difference of custom should exist, and it is better to follow the opinion which has not the least association with error and sin.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:30
verses.text: This being the case, receive with gladness the heavenly gift and the plainly divine command; for all that is transacted in the holy councils of the bishops is to be referred to the Divine will.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:31
verses.text: Therefore, when you have made known to all our beloved brethren the subject of this epistle, regard yourselves bound to accept what has gone before, and to arrange for the regular observance of this holy day, so that when, according to my long-cherished desire, I shall see you face to face, I may be able to celebrate with you this holy festival upon one and the same day; and may rejoice with you all in witnessing the cruelty of the devil destroyed by our efforts, through Divine grace, while our faith and peace and concord flourish throughout the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 9:32
verses.text: May God preserve you, beloved brethren".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:2
verses.text: —The daily wants of the Church supplied by the Emperor, and an account of his other virtues.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:3
verses.text: Thus did the emperor write to the absent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:4
verses.text: To those who attended the council, three hundred and eighteen in number, he manifested great kindness, addressing them with much gentleness, and presenting them with gifts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:5
verses.text: He ordered numerous couches to be prepared for their accommodation and entertained them all at one banquet.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:6
verses.text: Those who were most worthy he received at his own table, distributing the rest at the others.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:7
verses.text: Observing that some among them had had the right eye torn out, and learning that this mutilation had been undergone for the sake of religion, he placed his lips upon the wounds, believing that he would extract a blessing from the kiss.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:8
verses.text: After the conclusion of the feast, he again presented other gifts to them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:9
verses.text: He then wrote to the governors of the provinces, directing that provision-money should be given in every city to virgins and widows, and to those who were consecrated to the divine service; and he measured the amount of their annual allowance more by the impulse of his own generosity than by their need.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:10
verses.text: The third part of the sum is distributed to this day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:11
verses.text: Julian impiously withheld the whole.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:12
verses.text: His successor conferred the sum which is now dispensed, the famine which then prevailed having lessened the resources of the state.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:13
verses.text: If the pensions were formerly triple in amount to what they are at present, the generosity of the emperor can by this fact be easily seen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:14
verses.text: I do not account it right to pass over the following circumstance in silence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:15
verses.text: Some quarrelsome individuals wrote accusations against certain bishops, and presented their indictments to the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:16
verses.text: This occurring before the establishment of concord, he received the lists, formed them into a packet which he sealed with his ring, and ordered them to be kept safely.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:17
verses.text: After the reconciliation had been effected, he brought out these writings, and burnt them in their presence, at the same time declaring upon oath that he had not read a word of them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:18
verses.text: He said that the crimes of priests ought not to be made known to the multitude, lest they should become an occasion of offence, and lead them to sin without fear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:19
verses.text: It is reported also that he added that if he were to detect a bishop in the very act of committing adultery, he would throw his imperial robe over the unlawful deed, lest any should witness the scene, and be thereby injured.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 10:20
verses.text: Thus did he admonish all the priests, as well as confer honours upon them, and then exhorted them to return each to his own flock.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI  I shall here insert the letter respecting the faith, written by Eusebius, bishop of Caesarea, as it describes the effrontery of the Arians, who not only despise our fathers, but reject their own: it contains a convincing proof of their madness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:2
verses.text: They certainly honour Eusebius, because he adopted their sentiments, but yet they openly contradict his writings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:3
verses.text: He wrote this epistle to some of the Arians, who were accusing him, it seems, of treachery.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:4
verses.text: The letter itself explains the writer's object.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:5
verses.text: Epistle of Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea, which he wrote from Nicaea when the great Council was assembled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:6
verses.text: "You will have probably learnt from other sources what was decided respecting the faith of the church at the general council of Nicaea, for the fame of great transactions generally outruns the accurate account of them: but lest rumours not in strict accordance with the truth should reach you, I think it necessary to send to you, first, the formulary of faith originally proposed by us, and, next, the second, published with additions made to our terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:7
verses.text: The following is our formulary, which was read in the presence of our most pious emperor, and declared to be couched in right and proper language.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:8
verses.text: The Faith put forth by us.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:9
verses.text: "'As in our first catechetical instruction, and at the time of our baptism, we received from the bishops who were before us and as we have learnt from the Holy Scriptures, and, alike as presbyters, and as bishops, were wont to believe and teach; so we now believe and thus declare our faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:10
verses.text: It is as follows:—  "'We believe in one God, Father Almighty, the Maker of all things, visible and invisible; and in one Lord Jesus Christ, the Word of God, God of God, Light of Light, Life of Life, Only-begotten Son, First-born of every creature, begotten of the Father before all worlds; by Whom all things were made; Who for our salvation was incarnate, and lived among men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:11
verses.text: He suffered and rose again the third day, and ascended to the Father; and He will come again in glory to judge the quick and the dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:12
verses.text: We also believe in one Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:13
verses.text: "'We believe in the being and continual existence of each of these; that the Father is in truth the Father; the Son in truth the Son; the Holy Ghost in truth the Holy Ghost; as our Lord, when sending out His disciples to preach the Gospel, said, 'Go forth and teach all nations, baptizing them into the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:14
verses.text: ' We positively affirm that we hold this faith, that we have always held it, and that we adhere to it even unto death, condemning all ungodly heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:15
verses.text: We testify, as before God the Almighty and our Lord Jesus Christ, that we have thought thus from the heart, and from the soul, ever since we have known ourselves; and we have the means of showing, and, indeed, of convincing you, that we have always during the past thus believed and preached.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:16
verses.text: '  "When this formulary had been set forth by us, there was no room to gainsay it; but our beloved emperor himself was the first to testify that it was most orthodox, and that he coincided in opinion with it; and he exhorted the others to sign it, and to receive all the doctrine it contained, with the single addition of the one word—'consubstantial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:17
verses.text: ' He explained that this term implied no bodily condition or change, for that the Son did not derive His existence from the Father either by means of division or of abscission, since an immaterial, intellectual, and incorporeal nature could not be subject to any bodily condition or change.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:18
verses.text: These things must be understood as bearing a divine and mysterious signification.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:19
verses.text: Thus reasoned our wisest and most religious emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:20
verses.text: The addition of the word consubstantial has given occasion for the composition of the following formulary:—  The Creed published by the Council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:21
verses.text: "'We believe in one God, Father Almighty, Maker of all things visible and invisible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:22
verses.text: And in one Lord Jesus Christ, the Son of God, begotten of the Father; only-begotten, that is, of the substance of the Father, God of God, Light of Light, Very God of very God, begotten not made, being of one substance with the Father: by Whom all things were made both in heaven and on earth: Who for us men, and for our salvation, came down from heaven, and was incarnate, and was made man; He suffered, and rose gain the third day; He ascended into heaven, and is coming to judge both quick and dead.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:23
verses.text: And we believe in the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:24
verses.text: The holy Catholic and Apostolic Church anathematizes all who say that there was a time when the Son of God was not; that before He was begotten He was not; that He was made out of the non-existent; or that He is of a different essence and of a different substance from the Father; and that He is susceptible of variation or change.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:25
verses.text: '  "When they had set forth this formulary, we did not leave without examination that passage in which it is said that the Son is of the substance of the Father, and consubstantial with the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:26
verses.text: Questions and arguments thence arose, and the meaning of the terms was exactly tested.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:27
verses.text: Accordingly they were led to confess that the word consubstantial signifies that the Son is of the Father, but not as being a part of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:28
verses.text: We deemed it right to receive this opinion; for that is sound doctrine which teaches that the Son is of the Father, but not part of His substance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:29
verses.text: From the love of peace, and lest we should fall from the true belief, we also accept this view, neither do we reject the term 'consubstantial.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:30
verses.text: ' For the same reason we admitted the expression, 'begotten, but not made;' for they alleged that the word 'made' applies generally to all things which were created by the Son, to which the Son is in no respect similar; and that consequently He is not a created thing, like the things made by Him, but is of a substance superior to all created objects.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:31
verses.text: The Holy Scriptures teach Him to be begotten of the Father, by a mode of generation which is incomprehensible and inexplicable to all created beings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:32
verses.text: So also the term 'of one substance with the Father,' when investigated, was accepted not in accordance with bodily relations or similarity to mortal beings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:33
verses.text: For it was also shown that it does not either imply division of substance, nor abscission, nor any modification or change or diminution in the power of the Father, all of which are alien from the nature of the unbegotten Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:34
verses.text: It was concluded that the expression 'being of one substance with the Father,' implies that the Son of God does not resemble, in any one respect, the creatures which He has made; but that to the Father alone, who begat Him, He is in all points perfectly like: for He is of the essence and of the substance of none save of the Father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:35
verses.text: This interpretation having been given of the doctrine, it appeared right to us to assent to it, especially as we were aware that of the ancients some learned and celebrated bishops and writers have used the term 'consubstantial' with respect to the divinity of the Father and of the Son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:36
verses.text: "These are the circumstances which I had to communicate respecting the published formulary of the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:37
verses.text: To it we all agreed, not without investigation, but, after having subjected the views submitted to us to thorough examination in the presence of our most beloved emperor, for the above reasons we all acquiesced in it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:38
verses.text: We also allowed that the anathema appended by them to their formulary of faith should be accepted, because it prohibits the use of words which are not scriptural; through which almost all the disorder and troubles of the Church have arisen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:39
verses.text: And since no passage of the inspired Scripture uses the terms 'out of the non-existent,' or that 'there was a time when He was not,' nor indeed any of the other phrases of the same class, it did not appear reasonable to assert or to teach such things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:40
verses.text: In this opinion, therefore, we judged it right to agree; since, indeed, we had never, at any former period, been accustomed to use such terms.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:41
verses.text: Moreover, the condemnation of the assertion that before He was begotten He was not, did not appear to involve any incongruity, because all assent to the fact that He was the Son of God before He was begotten according to the flesh.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:42
verses.text: And here our emperor, most beloved by God, began to reason concerning His divine origin, and His existence before all ages.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:43
verses.text: He was virtually in the Father without generation, even before He was actually begotten, the Father having always been the Father, just as He has always been a King and a Saviour, and, virtually, all things, and has never known any change of being or action.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 11:44
verses.text: "We have thought it requisite, beloved brethren, to transmit you an account of these circumstances, in order to show you what examination and investigation we bestowed on all the questions which we had to decide; and also to prove how at one time we resisted firmly, even to the last hour, when doctrines improperly expressed offended us, and, at another time, we, without contention, accepted the articles which contained nothing objectionable, when after a thorough and candid investigation of their signification, they appeared perfectly conformable with what had been confessed by us in the formulary of faith which we had published".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:2
verses.text: —Confutation of the blasphemies of the Arians of our time, from the writings of Eusebius, Bishop of Caesarea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:3
verses.text: Eusebius clearly testifies that the aforesaid term "consubstantial" is not a new one, nor the invention of the fathers assembled at the council; but that, from the very first it has been handed down from father to son.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:4
verses.text: He states that all those then assembled unanimously received the creed then published; and he again bears testimony to the same fact in another work, in which he highly extols the conduct of the great Constantine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:5
verses.text: He writes as follows:—  "The emperor having delivered this discourse in Latin, it was translated into Greek by an interpreter, and then he gave liberty of speech to the leaders of the council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:6
verses.text: Some at once began to bring forward complaints against their neighbours, while others had recourse to recriminations and reproaches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:7
verses.text: Each party had much to urge, and at the beginning the debate waxed very violent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:8
verses.text: The emperor patiently and attentively listened to all that was advanced, and gave full attention to what was urged by each party in turn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:9
verses.text: He calmly endeavoured to reconcile the conflicting parties; addressing them mildly in Greek, of which language he was not ignorant, in a sweet and gentle manner.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:10
verses.text: Some he convinced by argument, others he put to the blush; he commended those who had spoken well, and excited all to unanimity; until, at length, he reduced them all to oneness of mind and opinion on all the disputed points, so that they all agreed to hold the same faith, and to celebrate the festival of Salvation upon the same day.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:11
verses.text: What had been decided was committed to writing, and was signed by all the bishops".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:12
verses.text: Soon after the author thus continues the narrative:—  "When matters had been thus arranged, the emperor gave them permission to return to their own dioceses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:13
verses.text: They returned with great joy, and have ever since continued to be of the one opinion, agreed upon in the presence of the emperor, and, though once widely separated, now united together, as it were, in one body.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:14
verses.text: Constantine, rejoicing in the success of his efforts, made known these happy results by letter to those who were at a distance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:15
verses.text: He ordered large sums of money to be liberally distributed both among the inhabitants of the country and of the cities, in order that the twentieth anniversary of his reign might be celebrated with public festivities".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:16
verses.text: Although the Arians impiously gainsay the statements of the other fathers, yet they ought to believe what has been written by this father, whom they have been accustomed to admire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:17
verses.text: They ought, therefore, to receive his testimony to the unanimity with which the confession of faith was signed by all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:18
verses.text: But, since they impugn the opinions of their own leaders, they ought to become acquainted with the most foul and terrible manner of the death of Arius and with all their powers to flee from the impious doctrine of which he was the parent.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 12:19
verses.text: As it is likely that the mode of his death is not known by all, I shall here relate it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:2
verses.text: —Extract from the Letter of Athanasius on the Death of Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:3
verses.text: After Arius had remained a long time in Alexandria, he endeavoured riotously to obtrude himself again into the assemblies of the Church, professing to renounce his impiety, and promising to receive the confession of faith drawn up by the fathers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:4
verses.text: But not succeeding in obtaining the confidence of the divine Alexander, nor of Athanasius, who followed Alexander alike in the patriarchate and in piety, he, helped and encouraged by Eusebius, bishop of Nicomedia, betook himself to Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:5
verses.text: The intrigues upon which he then entered, and their punishment by the righteous Judge are all best narrated by the excellent Athanasius, in his letter to Apion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:6
verses.text: I shall therefore now insert this passage in my work.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:7
verses.text: He writes:—  "I was not at Constantinople when he died; but Macarius, the presbyter, was there, and from him I learnt all the circumstances.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:8
verses.text: The emperor Constantine was induced by Eusebius and his party to send for Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:9
verses.text: Upon his arrival, the emperor asked him whether he held the faith of the Catholic church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:10
verses.text: Arius then swore that his faith was orthodox, and presented a written summary of his belief; concealing, however, the reasons of his ejection from the Church by the bishop Alexander, and making a dishonest use of the language of Holy Scripture.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:11
verses.text: When, therefore, he had declared upon oath that he did not hold the errors for which he had been expelled from the Church by Alexander, Constantine dismissed him, saying, 'If thy faith is orthodox, thou hast well sworn; but if thy faith is impious and yet thou hast sworn, let God from heaven judge thee.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:12
verses.text: ' When he quitted the emperor, the partizans of Eusebius, with their usual violence, desired to conduct him into the church; but Alexander, of blessed memory, bishop of Constantinople, refused his permission, alleging that the inventor of the heresy ought not to be admitted into communion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:13
verses.text: Then at last the partizans of Eusebius pronounced the threat: 'As, against your will, we succeeded in prevailing on the emperor to send for Arius, so now, even if you forbid it, shall Arius join in communion with us in this church to-morrow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:14
verses.text: ' It was on Saturday that they said this.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:15
verses.text: The bishop Alexander, deeply grieved at what he had heard, went into the church and poured forth his lamentations, raising his hands in supplication to God, and throwing himself on his face on the pavement in the sanctuary, prayed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:16
verses.text: Macarius went in with him, prayed with him, and heard his prayers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:17
verses.text: He asked one of two things.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:18
verses.text: 'If Arius,' said he, 'is to be joined to the Church to-morrow, let me Thy servant depart, and do not destroy the pious with the impious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:19
verses.text: If Thou wilt spare Thy Church, and I know that Thou dost spare her, look upon the words of the followers of Eusebius, and give not over Thy heritage to destruction and to shame.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:20
verses.text: Remove Arius, lest if he come into the Church, heresy seem to come in with him, and impiety be hereafter deemed piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:21
verses.text: ' Having thus prayed, the bishop left the church deeply anxious, and then a horrible and extraordinary catastrophe ensued.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:22
verses.text: The followers of Eusebius had launched out into threats, while the bishop had recourse to prayer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:23
verses.text: Arius, emboldened by the protection of his party, delivered many trifling and foolish speeches, when he was suddenly compelled by a call of nature to retire, and immediately, as it is written, 'falling headlong, he burst asunder in the midst,' and gave up the ghost, being deprived at once both of communion and of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:24
verses.text: This, then, was the end of Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:25
verses.text: The followers of Eusebius were covered with shame, and buried him whose belief they shared.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:26
verses.text: The blessed Alexander completed the celebration, rejoicing with the Church in piety and orthodoxy, praying with all the brethren and greatly glorifying God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:27
verses.text: This was not because he rejoiced at the death of Arius—God forbid; for 'it is appointed unto all men once to die;' but because the event plainly transcended any human condemnation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:28
verses.text: For the Lord Himself passing judgment upon the menaces of the followers of Eusebius, and the prayer of Alexander, condemned the Arian heresy, and shewed that it was unworthy of being received into the communion of the Church; thus manifesting to all that, even if it received the countenance and support of the emperor, and of all men, yet by truth itself it stood condemned".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:29
verses.text: These were the first fruits, reaped by Arius, of those pernicious seeds which he had himself sown, and formed the prelude to the punishments that awaited him hereafter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:30
verses.text: His impiety was condemned by his punishment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:31
verses.text: I shall now turn my narrative to the piety of the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:32
verses.text: He addressed a letter to all the subjects of the Roman empire, exhorting them to renounce their former errors, and to embrace the doctrines of our Saviour, and trying to guide them to this truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:33
verses.text: He stirred up the bishops in every city to build churches, and encouraged them not only by his letter, but also by presenting them with large sums of money, and defraying all the expenses of building.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 13:34
verses.text: This his own letter sets forth, which was after this manner:—.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:2
verses.text: —Letter written by the Emperor Constantine respecting the building of Churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:3
verses.text: "Constantinus Augustus, the great and the victorious, to Eusebius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:4
verses.text: "I am well aware, and am thoroughly convinced, my beloved brother, that as the servants of our Saviour Christ have been suffering up to the present time from nefarious machinations and tyrannical persecutions, the fabrics of all the churches must have either fallen into utter ruin from neglect, or, through apprehension of the impending iniquity, have been reduced below their proper dignity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:5
verses.text: But now that freedom is restored, and that dragon, through the providence of God, and by our instrumentality, thrust out from the government of the Empire, I think that the divine power has become known to all, and that those who hitherto, from fear or from incredulity or from depravity, have lived in error, will now, upon becoming acquainted with Him who truly is, be led into the true and correct manner of life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:6
verses.text: Exert yourself, therefore, diligently in the reparation of the churches under your own jurisdiction, and admonish the principal bishops, priests, and deacons of other places to engage zealously in the same work; in order that all the churches which still exist may be repaired or enlarged, and that new ones may be built wherever they are required.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:7
verses.text: You, and others through your intervention, can apply to magistrates and to provincial governments, for all that may be necessary for this purpose; for they have received written injunctions to render zealous obedience to whatever your holiness may command.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:8
verses.text: May God preserve you, beloved brother".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:9
verses.text: Thus the emperor wrote to the bishops in each province respecting the building of churches.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 14:10
verses.text: From his letter to Eusebius of Palestine, it is easily learnt what measures he adopted to obtain copies of the Holy Bible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:2
verses.text: —The Epistle of Constantine concerning the preparation of copies of the Holy Scriptures.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:3
verses.text: "Constantinus Augustus, the great and the victorious, to Eusebius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:4
verses.text: "In the city which bears our name, a great number of persons have, through the providential care of God the Saviour, united themselves to the holy Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:5
verses.text: As all things there are in a state of rapid improvement, we deemed it most important that an additional number of churches should be built.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:6
verses.text: Adopt joyfully the mode of procedure determined upon by us, which we have thought expedient to make known to your prudence, namely, that you should get written, on fine parchment, fifty volumes, easily legible and handy for use; these you must have transcribed by skilled calligraphers, accurately acquainted with their art.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:7
verses.text: I mean, of course, copies of the Holy Scriptures, which, as you know, it is most necessary that the congregation of the Church should both have and use.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:8
verses.text: A letter has been sent from our clemency to the catholicus of the diocese, in order that he may be careful that everything necessary for the undertaking is supplied.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:9
verses.text: The duty devolving upon you is to take measures to ensure the completion of these manuscripts within a short space of time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:10
verses.text: When they are finished, you are authorised by this letter to order two public carriages for the purpose of transmitting them to us; and thus the fair manuscripts will be easily submitted to our inspection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:11
verses.text: Appoint one of the deacons of your church to take charge of this part of the business; when he comes to us, he shall receive proofs of our benevolence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:12
verses.text: May God preserve you, beloved brother".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:13
verses.text: What has been already said is enough to shew, nay to clearly prove, how great zeal the emperor manifested on the matters of religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:14
verses.text: I will, however, add his noble acts with regard to the Sepulchre of our Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:15
verses.text: For having learnt that the idolaters, in their frantic rage, had heaped earth over the Lord's tomb, eager thus to destroy all remembrance of His Salvation, and had built over it a temple to the goddess of unbridled lust, in mockery of the Virgin's birth, the emperor ordered the foul shrine to be demolished, and the soil polluted with abominable sacrifices to be carried away and thrown out far from the city, and a new temple of great size and beauty to be erected on the site.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:16
verses.text: All this is clearly set forth in the letter which he wrote to the president of the church of Jerusalem, Macarius, whom we have already mentioned as a member of the great Nicene Council, and united with his brethren in withstanding the blasphemies of Arius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 15:17
verses.text: The following is the letter.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:2
verses.text: —Letter from the Emperor to Macarius, Bishop of Jerusalem, concerning the building of the Holy Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:3
verses.text: "Constantinus, the victorious and the great, to Macarius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:4
verses.text: "The grace of our Saviour is so wonderful, that no words are adequate to express the present marvel.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:5
verses.text: The fact that the monument of His most holy sufferings should have remained concealed beneath the earth, during so long a course of years, until the time when, on the death of the common enemy of all, it was destined to shine forth on His liberated servants, surpasses every other subject of admiration.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:6
verses.text: If all the wise men throughout the world were collected into one place, and were to endeavour to express themselves worthily of it, they could not approach within an infinite distance of it; for this miracle is as much beyond all human power of belief, as heavenly things by their nature are mightier than human.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:7
verses.text: Hence it is my first and only object that, as by new miracles the faith in the truth is daily confirmed, so the minds of us all may be more earnestly devoted to the holy law, wisely, zealously, and with one accord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:8
verses.text: As my design is, I think, now generally known, I desire that you, above all, should be assured that my most intense anxiety is to decorate with beautiful edifices that consecrated spot, which by God's command I have relieved from the burden of the foul idol which encumbered it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:9
verses.text: For from the beginning He declared it holy, and has rendered it still more holy from the time that He brought to light the proof and memorial of the sufferings of our Lord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:10
verses.text: I trust, then, to your sagacity to take every necessary care, not only that the basilica itself surpass all others; but that all its arrangements be such that this building may be incomparably superior to the most beautiful structures in every city throughout the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:11
verses.text: We have entrusted our friend Dracilianus, who discharges the functions of the most illustrious praefect of the province, with the superintendence of the work of the erection and decoration of the walls.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:12
verses.text: He has received our orders to engage workmen and artisans, and to provide all that you may deem requisite for the building.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:13
verses.text: Let us know, by letter, when you have inspected the work, what columns or marbles you consider would be most ornamental, in order that whatever you may inform us is necessary for the work may be conveyed thither from all quarters of the world.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:14
verses.text: For that which is of all places the most wonderful, ought to be decorated in accordance with its dignity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:15
verses.text: I wish to learn from you whether you think that the vaulted roof of the basilica ought to be panelled, or to be adorned in some other way; for if it is to be panelled it may also be gilt.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:16
verses.text: Your holiness must signify to the aforesaid officers, as soon as possible, what workmen and artificers, and what sums of money, are requisite; and let me know promptly not only about the marbles and columns, but also about the panelled ceiling, if you decide that this will be the most beautiful mode of construction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 16:17
verses.text: May God preserve you, beloved brother".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:2
verses.text: —Helena, Mother of the Emperor Constantine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:3
verses.text: —Her zeal in the Erection of the Holy Church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:4
verses.text: The bearer of these letters was no less illustrious a personage than the mother of the emperor, even she who was glorious in her offspring, whose piety was celebrated by all; she who brought forth that great luminary and nurtured him in piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:5
verses.text: She did not shrink from the fatigue of the journey on account of her extreme old age, but undertook it a little before her death, which occurred in her eightieth year.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:6
verses.text: When the empress beheld the place where the Saviour suffered, she immediately ordered the idolatrous temple, which had been there erected, to be destroyed, and the very earth on which it stood to be removed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:7
verses.text: When the tomb, which had been so long concealed, was discovered, three crosses were seen buried near the Lord's sepulchre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:8
verses.text: All held it as certain that one of these crosses was that of our Lord Jesus Christ, and that the other two were those of the thieves who were crucified with Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:9
verses.text: Yet they could not discern to which of the three the Body of the Lord had been brought nigh, and which had received the outpouring of His precious Blood.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:10
verses.text: But the wise and holy Macarius, the president of the city, resolved this question in the following manner.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:11
verses.text: He caused a lady of rank, who had been long suffering from disease, to be touched by each of the crosses, with earnest prayer, and thus discerned the virtue residing in that of the Saviour.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:12
verses.text: For the instant this cross was brought near the lady, it expelled the sore disease, and made her whole.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:13
verses.text: The mother of the emperor, on learning the accomplishment of her desire, gave orders that a portion of the nails should be inserted in the royal helmet, in order that the head of her son might be preserved from the darts of his enemies.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:14
verses.text: The other portion of the nails she ordered to be formed into the bridle of his horse, not only to ensure the safety of the emperor, but also to fulfil an ancient prophecy; for long before Zechariah, the prophet, had predicted that "There shall be upon the bridles of the horses Holiness unto the Lord Almighty".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:15
verses.text: She had part of the cross of our Saviour conveyed to the palace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:16
verses.text: The rest was enclosed in a covering of silver, and committed to the care of the bishop of the city, whom she exhorted to preserve it carefully, in order that it might be transmitted uninjured to posterity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:17
verses.text: She then sent everywhere for workmen and for materials, and caused the most spacious and most magnificent churches to be erected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:18
verses.text: It is unnecessary to describe their beauty and grandeur; for all the pious, if I may so speak, hasten thither and behold the magnificence of the buildings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:19
verses.text: This celebrated and admirable empress performed another action worthy of being remembered.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:20
verses.text: She assembled all the women who had vowed perpetual virginity, and placing them on couches, she herself fulfilled the duties of a handmaid, serving them with food and handing them cups and pouring out wine, and bringing a basin and pitcher, and pouring out water to wash their hands.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:21
verses.text: After performing these and other laudable actions, the empress returned to her son, and not long after, she joyfully entered upon the other and a better life, after having given her son much pious advice and her fervent parting blessing.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 17:22
verses.text: After her death, those honours were rendered to her memory which her stedfast and zealous service to God deserved.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:2
verses.text: —The Unlawful Translation of Eusebius, Bishop of Nicomedia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:3
verses.text: The Arian party did not desist from their evil machinations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:4
verses.text: They had only signed the confession of faith for the purpose of disguising themselves in sheeps'-skins, while they were acting the part of wolves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:5
verses.text: The holy Alexander, of Byzantium, for the city was not yet called Constantinople, who by his prayer had pierced Arius to the heart, had, at the period to which we are referring, been translated to a better life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:6
verses.text: Eusebius, the propagator of impiety, little regarding the definition which, only a short time previously, he with the other bishops had agreed upon, without delay quitted Nicomedia and seized upon the see of Constantinople, in direct violation of that canon which prohibits bishops and presbyters from being translated from one city to another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:7
verses.text: But that those who carry their infatuation so far as to deny the divinity of the only-begotten Son of God, should likewise violate the other laws, cannot excite surprise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:8
verses.text: Nor was this the first occasion that he made this innovation; for, having been originally entrusted with the see of Berytus, he leapt from thence to Nicomedia.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:9
verses.text: Whence he was expelled by the synod, on account of his manifest impiety, as was likewise Theognis, bishop of Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 18:10
verses.text: This is related a second time in the letters of the emperor Constantine; and I shall here insert the close of the letter which he wrote to the Nicomedians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:2
verses.text: —Epistle of the Emperor Constantine against Eusebius and Theognis, addressed to the Nicomedians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:3
verses.text: "Who has taught these doctrines to the innocent multitude? It is manifestly Eusebius, the co-operator in the cruelty of the tyrants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:4
verses.text: For that he was the creature of the tyrant has been clearly shown; and, indeed, is proved by the slaughter of the bishops, and by the fact that these victims were true bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:5
verses.text: The relentless persecution of the Christians proclaims this fact aloud.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:6
verses.text: "I shall not here say anything of the insults directed against me, by which the conspiracies of the opposite faction were mainly carried out.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:7
verses.text: But he went so far as to send spies to watch me, and scarcely refrained from raising troops in aid of the tyrant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:8
verses.text: Let not any one imagine that I allege what I am not prepared to prove.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:9
verses.text: I am in possession of clear evidence; for I have caused the bishops and presbyters belonging to his following to be seized.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:10
verses.text: But I pass over all these facts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:11
verses.text: I only mention them for the purpose of making these persons ashamed of their conduct, and not from any feeling of resentment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:12
verses.text: "There is one thing I fear, one thing which causes me anxiety, and that is to see you charged as accomplices; for you are influenced by the doctrines of Eusebius, and have thus been led away from the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:13
verses.text: But your cure will be speedy, if, after obtaining a bishop who holds pure and faithful doctrines, you will but look unto God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:14
verses.text: This depends upon you alone; and you would, no doubt, have thus acted long ago, had not the aforesaid Eusebius come here, strongly supported by those then in power, and overturned all discipline.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:15
verses.text: "As it is necessary to say something more about Eusebius, your patience will remember that a council was held in the city of Nicaea, at which, in obedience to my conscience, I was present, being actuated by no other motive than the desire of producing unanimity among all, and before all else of proving and dispelling the mischief which originated from the infatuation of Arius of Alexandria, and was straightway strengthened by the absurd and pernicious machinations of Eusebius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:16
verses.text: But, beloved and much-honoured brethren, you know not how earnestly and how disgracefully Eusebius, although convicted by the testimony of his own conscience, persevered in the support of the false doctrines which had been universally condemned.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:17
verses.text: He secretly sent persons to me to petition on his behalf, and personally intreated my assistance in preventing his being ejected from his bishopric, although his crimes had been fully detected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:18
verses.text: God, who, I trust, will continue His goodness towards you and towards me, is witness to the truth of what I say.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:19
verses.text: I was then myself deluded and deceived by Eusebius, as you shall well know.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:20
verses.text: In everything he acted according to his own desire, his mind being full of every kind of secret evil.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:21
verses.text: "Omitting the relation of the rest of his misdeeds, it is well that you should be informed of the crime which he lately perpetrated in concert with Theognis, the accomplice of his folly.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:22
verses.text: I had sent orders for the apprehension of certain individuals in Alexandria who had deserted our faith, and by whose means the firebrand of dissension was kindled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:23
verses.text: But these good gentlemen, forsooth, bishops, whom, by the clemency of the council, I had reserved for penitence, not only received them under their protection, but also participated in their evil deeds.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:24
verses.text: Hence I came to the determination to punish these ungrateful men, by apprehending and banishing them to some far-distant region.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:25
verses.text: "It is now your duty to look unto God with that same faith which it is clear that you have ever held, and in which it is fitting you should abide.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:26
verses.text: So let us have cause of rejoicing in the appointment of pure, orthodox, and beneficent bishops.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:27
verses.text: If any one should make mention of those destroyers, or presume to speak in their praise, let him know that his audacity will be repressed by the authority which has been committed to me as the servant of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:28
verses.text: May God preserve you, beloved brethren!"  The above-mentioned bishops were then deposed and banished.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:29
verses.text: Amphion was entrusted with the church of Nicomedia, and Chrestus with that of Nicaea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 19:30
verses.text: But the exiled bishops, employing their customary artifices, abused the benevolence of the emperor, renewed the previous contests, and regained their former power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:2
verses.text: —The artful Machinations of Eusebius and his followers against the Holy Eustathius, Bishop of Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:3
verses.text: Eusebius, as I have already stated, seized the diocese of Constantinople by force.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:4
verses.text: And thus having acquired great power in that city, frequently visiting and holding familiar intercourse with the emperor, he gained confidence and formed plots against those who were foremost in the support of the truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:5
verses.text: He at first feigned a desire of going to Jerusalem, to see the celebrated edifices there erected: and the emperor, who was deceived by his flattery, allowed him to set out with the utmost honour, providing him with carriages, and the rest of his equipage and retinue.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:6
verses.text: Theognis, bishop of Nicaea, who, as we have before said, was his accomplice in his evil designs, travelled with him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:7
verses.text: When they arrived at Antioch, they put on the mask of friendship, and were received with the utmost deference.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:8
verses.text: Eustathius, the great champion of the faith, treated them with fraternal kindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:9
verses.text: When they arrived at the holy places, they had an interview with those who were of the same opinions as themselves, namely, Eusebius, bishop of Caesarea, Patrophilus, bishop of Scythopolis, Aetius, bishop of Lydda, Theodotus, bishop of Laodicea, and others who had imbibed the Arian sentiments; they made known the plot they had hatched to them, and went with them to Antioch.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:10
verses.text: The pretext for their journey was, that due honour might be rendered to Eusebius; but their real motive was their war against religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:11
verses.text: They bribed a low woman, who made a traffic of her beauty, to sell them her tongue, and then repaired to the council, and when all the spectators had been ordered to retire, they introduced the wretched woman.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:12
verses.text: She held a babe in her arms, of which she loudly and impudently affirmed that Eustathius was the father.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:13
verses.text: Eustathius, conscious of his innocence, asked her whether she could bring forward any witness to prove what she had advanced.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:14
verses.text: She replied that she could not: yet these equitable judges admitted her to oath, although it is said in the law, that "at the mouth of two or three witnesses shall the matter be established;" and the apostle says, "against an elder receive not any accusation but before two or three witnesses".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:15
verses.text: But they despised these divine laws, and admitted the accusation against this great man without any witnesses.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:16
verses.text: When the woman had again declared upon oath that Eustathius was the father of the babe, these truth-loving judges condemned him as an adulterer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:17
verses.text: When the other bishops, who upheld the apostolical doctrines, being ignorant of all these intrigues, openly opposed the sentence, and advised Eustathius not to submit to it, the originators of the plot promptly repaired to the emperor, and endeavoured to persuade him that the accusation was true, and the sentence of deposition just; and they succeeded in obtaining the banishment of this champion of piety and chastity, as an adulterer and a tyrant.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 20:18
verses.text: He was conducted across Thrace to a city of Illyricum.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:2
verses.text: —Bishops of Heretical opinions ordained in Antioch after the Banishment of St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:3
verses.text: Eustathius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:4
verses.text: Eulalius was first consecrated in place of Eustathius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:5
verses.text: But Eulalius surviving his elevation only a short period, it was intended that Eusebius of Palestine should be translated to this bishopric.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:6
verses.text: Eusebius, however, refused the appointment, and the emperor forbade its being conferred on him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:7
verses.text: Next Euphronius was put forward, who also dying, after a lapse of only one year and a few months, the see was conferred on Flaccillus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:8
verses.text: All these bishops secretly clung to the Arian heresy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:9
verses.text: Hence it was that most of those individuals, whether of the clergy or of the laity, who valued the true religion, left the churches and formed assemblies among themselves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:10
verses.text: They were called Eustathians, since it was after the banishment of Eustathius that they began to hold their meetings.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:11
verses.text: The wretched woman above-mentioned was soon after attacked by a severe and protracted illness, and then avowed the imposture in which she had been engaged, and made known the whole plot, not only to two or three, but to a very large number of priests.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:12
verses.text: She confessed that she had been bribed to bring this false and impudent charge, but yet that her oath was not altogether false, as a certain Eustathius, a coppersmith, was the father of the babe.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 21:13
verses.text: Such were some of the crimes perpetrated in Antioch by this most excellent faction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:2
verses.text: —Conversion of the Indians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:3
verses.text: At this period, the light of the knowledge of God was for the first time shed upon India.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:4
verses.text: The courage and the piety of the emperor had become celebrated throughout the world; and the barbarians, having learnt by experience to choose peace rather than war, were able to enjoy intercourse with one another without fear.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:5
verses.text: Many persons, therefore, set out on long journeys; some for the desire of making discoveries, others from a spirit of commercial enterprise.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:6
verses.text: About this period a native of Tyre, acquainted with Greek philosophy, desiring to penetrate into the interior of India, set off for this purpose with his two young nephews.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:7
verses.text: When he had accomplished the object of his wishes, he embarked for his own country.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:8
verses.text: The ship being compelled to put in to land in order to obtain a fresh supply of water, the barbarians fell upon her, drowned some of the crew, and took the others prisoners.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:9
verses.text: The uncle was among the number of those who were killed, and the lads were conducted to the king.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:10
verses.text: The name of the one was aedesius, and of the other Frumentius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:11
verses.text: The king of the country, in course of time, perceiving their intelligence, promoted them to the superintendence of his household.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:12
verses.text: If any one should doubt the truth of this account, let him recall to mind the history of Joseph in the kingdom of Egypt, and also the history of Daniel, and of the three champions of the truth, who, from being captives, became princes of Babylon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:13
verses.text: The king died; but these young men remained with his son, and were advanced to still greater power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:14
verses.text: As they had been brought up in the true religion, they exhorted the merchants who visited the country to assemble, according to the custom of Romans, to take part in the divine liturgy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:15
verses.text: After a considerable time they solicited the king to reward their services by permitting them to return to their own country.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:16
verses.text: They obtained his permission, and safely reached Roman territory.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:17
verses.text: aedesius directed his course towards Tyre, but Frumentius, whose religious zeal was greater than the natural feeling of affection for his relatives, proceeded to Alexandria, and informed the bishop of that city that the Indians were deeply anxious to obtain spiritual light.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:18
verses.text: Athanasius then held the rudder of that church; he heard the story, and then "Who," said he, "better than you yourself can scatter the mists of ignorance, and introduce among this people the light of Divine preaching?" After having said this, he conferred upon him the episcopal dignity, and sent him to the spiritual culture of that nation.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:19
verses.text: The newly-ordained bishop left this country, caring nothing for the mighty ocean, and returned to the untilled ground of his work.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 22:20
verses.text: There, having the grace of God to labour with him, he cheerfully and successfully played the husbandman, catching those who sought to gainsay his words by works of apostolic wonder, and thus, by these marvels, confirming his teaching, he continued each day to take many souls alive.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:2
verses.text: —Conversion of the Iberians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:3
verses.text: Frumentius thus led the Indians to the knowledge of God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:4
verses.text: Iberia, about the same time, was guided into the way of truth by a captive woman.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:5
verses.text: She continued instant in prayer, allowing herself no softer bed than a sack spread upon the ground, and accounted fasting her highest luxury.
