verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:6
verses.text: This austerity was rewarded by gifts similar to those of the Apostles.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:7
verses.text: The barbarians, who were ignorant of medicine, were accustomed, when attacked by disease, to go to one another's houses, in order to ask those who had suffered in a similar way, and had got well, by what means they had been cured.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:8
verses.text: In accordance with this custom, a mother who had a sick child, repaired to this admirable woman, to enquire if she knew of any cure for the disease.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:9
verses.text: The latter took the child, placed it upon her bed, and prayed to the Creator of the world to be propitious to it, and cure the disease.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:10
verses.text: He heard her prayer, and made it whole.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:11
verses.text: This extraordinary woman hence obtained great celebrity; and the queen, who was suffering from a severe disease, hearing of her by report, sent for her.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:12
verses.text: The captive held herself in very low estimation, and would not accept the invitation of the queen.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:13
verses.text: But the queen, forced by her sore need, and careless of her royal dignity, herself ran to the captive.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:14
verses.text: The latter made the queen lie down upon her mean bed, and once again applied to her disease the efficacious remedy of prayer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:15
verses.text: The queen was healed, and offered as rewards for her cure, gold, silver, tunics, and mantles, and such gifts as she thought worthy of possession, and such as royal munificence should bestow.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:16
verses.text: The holy woman told her that she did not want any of these, but that she would deem her greatest reward to be the queen's knowledge of true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:17
verses.text: She then, as far as in her lay, explained the Divine doctrines, and exhorted her to erect a church in honour of Christ who had made her whole.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:18
verses.text: The queen then returned to the palace, and excited the admiration of her consort, by the suddenness of her cure; she then made known to him the power of that God whom the captive adored, and besought him to acknowledge the one only God, and to erect a church to Him, and to lead all the nation to worship Him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:19
verses.text: The king was greatly delighted with the miracle which had been performed upon the queen, but he would not consent to erect a church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:20
verses.text: A short time after he went out hunting, and the loving Lord made a prey of him as He did of Paul; for a sudden darkness enveloped him and forbade him to move from the spot; while those who were hunting with him enjoyed the customary sunlight, and he alone was bound with the fetters of blindness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:21
verses.text: In his perplexity he found a way of escape, for calling to mind his former unbelief, he implored the help of the God of the captive woman, and immediately the darkness was dispelled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:22
verses.text: He then went to the marvellous captive, and asked her to shew him how a church ought to be built.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:23
verses.text: He who once filled Bezaleel with architectural skill, graciously enabled this woman to devise the plan of a church.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:24
verses.text: The woman set about the plan, and men began to dig and build.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:25
verses.text: When the edifice was completed, the roof put on, and every thing supplied except the priests, this admirable woman found means to obtain these also.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:26
verses.text: For she persuaded the king to send an embassy to the Roman emperor asking for teachers of religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:27
verses.text: The king accordingly despatched an embassy for the purpose.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:28
verses.text: The emperor Constantine, who was warmly attached to the cause of religion, when informed of the purport of the embassy, gladly welcomed the ambassadors, and selected a bishop endowed with great faith, wisdom, and virtue, and presenting him with many gifts, sent him to the Iberians, that he might make known to them the true God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:29
verses.text: Not content with having granted the requests of the Iberians, he of his own accord undertook the protection of the Christians in Persia; for, learning that they were persecuted by the heathens, and that their king himself, a slave to error, was contriving various cunning plots for their destruction, he wrote to him, entreating him to embrace the Christian religion himself, as well as to honour its professors.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 23:30
verses.text: His own letter will render his earnestness in the cause the plainer.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:2
verses.text: —Letter written by the Emperor Constantine to Sapor, the King of Persia, respecting the Christians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:3
verses.text: "In protecting the holy faith I enjoy the light of truth, and by following the light of truth I attain to fuller knowledge of the faith.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:4
verses.text: Therefore, as facts prove, I recognize that most holy worship as teaching the knowledge of the most holy God.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:5
verses.text: This service I profess.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:6
verses.text: With the Power of this God for my ally, beginning at the furthest boundaries of the ocean, I have, one after another, quickened every part of the world with hope.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:7
verses.text: Now all the peoples once enslaved by many tyrants, worn by their daily miseries, and almost extinct, have been kindled to fresh life by receiving the protection of the State.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:8
verses.text: "The God I reverence is He whose emblem my dedicated troops bear on their shoulders, marching whithersoever the cause of justice leads them, and rewarding me by their splendid victories.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:9
verses.text: I confess that I reverence this God with eternal remembrance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:10
verses.text: Him, who dwelleth in the highest heavens, I contemplate with pure and unpolluted mind.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:11
verses.text: On Him I call on bended knees, shunning all abominable blood, all unseemly and ill-omened odours, all fire of incantation, and all pollution by which unlawful and shameful error has destroyed whole nations and hurled them down to hell.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:12
verses.text: "God does not permit those gifts which, in His beneficent Providence, He has bestowed upon men for the supply of their wants to be perverted according to every man's desire.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:13
verses.text: He only requires of men a pure mind and a spotless soul, and by these He weighs their deeds of virtue and piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:14
verses.text: He is pleased with gentleness and modesty; He loves the meek, and hates those who excite contentions; He loves faith, chastises unbelief; He breaks all power of boasting, and punishes the insolence of the proud.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:15
verses.text: Men exalted with pride He utterly overthrows, and rewards the humble and the patient according to their deserts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:16
verses.text: Of a just sovereignty He maketh much, strengthens it by His aid, and guards the counsels of Princes with the blessing of peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:17
verses.text: "I know that I am not in error, my brother, when I confess that this God is the Ruler and the Father of all men, a truth which many who preceded me upon the imperial throne were so deluded by error as to attempt to deny.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:18
verses.text: But their end was so dreadful that they have become a fearful warning to all mankind, to deter others from similar iniquity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:19
verses.text: Of these I count that man one whom the wrath of God, like a thunderbolt, drove hence into your country, and who made notorious the memorial of his shame which exists in your own land.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:20
verses.text: Indeed it appears to have been well ordered that the age in which we live should be distinguished by the open and manifest punishments inflicted on such persons.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:21
verses.text: I myself have witnessed the end of those who have persecuted the people of God by unlawful edicts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:22
verses.text: Hence it is that I more especially thank God for having now, by His special Providence, restored peace to those who observe His law, in which they exalt and rejoice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:23
verses.text: "I am led to expect future happiness and security whenever God in His goodness unites all men in the exercise of the one pure and true religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:24
verses.text: You may therefore well understand how exceedingly I rejoice to hear that the finest provinces of Persia are adorned abundantly with men of this class; I mean Christians; for it is of them I am speaking.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:25
verses.text: All then is well with you and with them, for you will have the Lord of all merciful and beneficent to you.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:26
verses.text: Since then you are so mighty and so pious, I commend the Christians to your care, and leave them in your protection.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:27
verses.text: Treat them, I beseech you, with the affection that befits your goodness.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:28
verses.text: Your fidelity in this respect will confer on yourself and on us inexpressible benefits".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:29
verses.text: This excellent emperor felt so much solicitude for all who had embraced the true religion, that he not only watched over those who were his own subjects, but also over the subjects of other sovereigns.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:30
verses.text: For this reason he was blessed with the special protection of God, so that although he held the reins of the whole of Europe and of Africa, and the greater part of Asia, his subjects were all well disposed to his rule, and obedient to his government.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:31
verses.text: Foreign nations submitted to his sway, some by voluntary submission, others overcome in war.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:32
verses.text: Trophies were everywhere erected, and the emperor was styled Victorious.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:33
verses.text: The praises of Constantine have, however, been proclaimed by many other writers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:34
verses.text: We must resume the thread of our history.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:35
verses.text: This emperor, who deserves the highest fame, devoted his whole mind to matters worthy of the apostles, while men who had been admitted to the sacerdotal dignity not only neglected to edify the church, but endeavoured to uproot it from the very foundations.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:36
verses.text: They invented all manner of false accusations against those who governed the church in accordance with the doctrines taught by the apostles, and did their best to depose and banish them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:37
verses.text: Their envy was not satisfied by the infamous falsehood which they had invented against Eustathius, but they had recourse to every artifice to effect the overthrow of another great bulwark of religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 24:38
verses.text: These tragic occurrences I shall now relate as concisely as possible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:2
verses.text: —An account of the plot formed against the Holy Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:3
verses.text: Alexander, that admirable bishop, who had successfully withstood the blasphemies of Arius, died five months after the council of Nicaea, and was succeeded in the episcopate of the church of Alexandria by Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:4
verses.text: Trained from his youth in sacred studies, Athanasius had attracted general admiration in each ecclesiastical office that he filled.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:5
verses.text: He had, at the general council, so defended the doctrines of the apostles, that while he won the approbation of all the champions of the truth, its opponents learned to look on their antagonist as a personal foe and public enemy.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:6
verses.text: He had attended the council as one of the retinue of Alexander, then a very young man, although he was the principal deacon.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:7
verses.text: When those who had denied the only-begotten Son of God heard that the helm of the Church of Alexandria had been entrusted to his hands knowing as they did by experience his zeal for the truth, they thought that his rule would prove the destruction of their authority.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:8
verses.text: They, therefore, resorted to the following machinations against him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:9
verses.text: In order to avert suspicion, they bribed some of the adherents of Meletius, who, although deposed by the council of Nicaea, had persevered in exciting commotions in the Thebaid and in the adjacent part of Egypt, and persuaded them to go to the emperor, and to accuse Athanasius of levying a tax upon Egypt, and giving the gold collected to a certain man who was preparing to usurp the imperial power.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:10
verses.text: The emperor being deceived by this story, Athanasius was brought to Constantinople.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:11
verses.text: Upon his arrival he proved that the accusation was false, and had the charge given him by God restored to him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:12
verses.text: This is shown by a letter from the emperor to the Church of Alexandria of which I shall transcribe only the concluding paragraph.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:13
verses.text: A Portion of the Letter from the Emperor Constantine to the Alexandrians.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:14
verses.text: "Believe me, my brethren, the wicked men were unable to effect anything against your bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:15
verses.text: They surely could have had no other design than to waste our time, and to leave themselves no place for repentance in this life.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:16
verses.text: Do you, therefore, help yourselves, and love that which wins your love; and exert all your power in the expulsion of those who wish to destroy your concord.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:17
verses.text: Look unto God, and love one another.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 25:18
verses.text: I joyfully welcomed Athanasius your bishop; and I have conversed with him as with one whom I know to be a man of God".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:2
verses.text: —Another plot against Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:3
verses.text: The calumniators of Athanasius, however, did not desist from their attempts.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:4
verses.text: On the contrary, they devised so bold a fiction against him, that it surpassed every invention of the ancient writers of the tragic or comic stage.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:5
verses.text: They again bribed individuals of the same party, and brought them before the emperor, vociferously accusing that champion of virtue of many abominable crimes.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:6
verses.text: The leaders of the party were Eusebius, Theognis, and Theodorus, bishop of Perinthus, a city now called Heraclea.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:7
verses.text: After having accused Athanasius of crimes which they described as too shocking to be tolerated, or even listened to, they persuaded the emperor to convene a council at Caesarea in Palestine, where Athanasius had many enemies, and to command that his cause should be there tried.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:8
verses.text: The emperor, utterly ignorant of the plot that had been devised, was persuaded by them to give the required order.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:9
verses.text: But the holy Athanasius, well aware of the malevolence of those who were to try him, refused to appear at the council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:10
verses.text: This served as a pretext to those who opposed the truth to criminate him still further; and they accused him before the emperor of contumacy and arrogance.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:11
verses.text: Nor were their hopes altogether frustrated; for the emperor, although exceedingly forbearing, became exasperated by their representations, and wrote to him in an angry manner, commanding him to repair to Tyre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:12
verses.text: Here the council was ordered to assemble, from the suspicion, as I think, that Athanasius had an apprehension of Caesarea on account of its bishop.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:13
verses.text: The emperor wrote also to the council in a style consistent with his devoted piety.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 26:14
verses.text: His letter is as follows.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:2
verses.text: —Epistle of the Emperor Constantine to the Council of Tyre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:3
verses.text: "Constantinus Augustus to the holy council assembled in Tyre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:4
verses.text: "In the general prosperity which distinguishes the present time, it seems right that the Catholic Church should likewise be exempt from trouble, and that the servants of Christ should be freed from every reproach.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:5
verses.text: "But certain individuals instigated by the mad desire of contention, not to say leading a life unworthy of their profession, are endeavoring to throw all into disorder.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:6
verses.text: This appears to me to be the greatest of all possible calamities.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:7
verses.text: I beseech you, therefore, in post haste, as the phrase goes, to assemble together, without any delay, in formal synod; so that you may support those who require your assistance, heal the brethren who are in danger, restore unanimity to the divided members, and rectify the disorders of the Church while time permits; and thus restore to those great provinces the harmony which, alas! the arrogance of a few men has destroyed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:8
verses.text: I believe every one would admit that you could not perform anything so pleasing in the sight of God, so surpassing all my prayers as well as your own, or so conducive to your own reputation, as to restore peace.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:9
verses.text: "Do not ye therefore delay, but when you have come together with all that sincerity and fidelity which our Saviour demands of all His servants, almost in words that we can hear, endeavour with redoubled eagerness to put a fitting end to these dissensions.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:10
verses.text: "Nothing shall be omitted on my part to further the interests of our religion.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:11
verses.text: I have done all that you recommended in your letters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:12
verses.text: I have sent to those bishops whom you specified, directing them to repair to the council for the purpose of deliberating with you upon ecclesiastical matters.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:13
verses.text: I have also sent Dionysius, a man of consular rank, to counsel those who are to sit in synod with you, and to be himself an eye witness of your proceedings, and particularly of the order and regularity that is maintained.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:14
verses.text: If any one should dare on the present occasion also to disobey our command, and refuse to come to the council, which, however, I do not anticipate, an officer will be despatched immediately to send him into banishment by imperial order, that he may learn not to oppose the decrees enacted by the emperor for the support of truth.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:15
verses.text: "All that now devolves upon your holinesses is to decide with unanimous judgment, without partiality or prejudice, in accordance with the ecclesiastical and apostolical rule, and to devise suitable remedies for the offences which may have resulted from error; in order that the Church may be freed from all reproach, that my anxiety may be diminished, that peace may be restored to those now at variance, and that your renown may be increased.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:16
verses.text: May God preserve you, beloved brethren".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:17
verses.text: The bishops accordingly repaired to the council of Tyre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:18
verses.text: Amongst them were those who were accused of holding heterodox doctrines; of whom Asclepas, bishop of Gaza, was one.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:19
verses.text: The admirable Athanasius also attended.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 27:20
verses.text: I shall first dwell on the tragedy of the accusation, and shall then relate the proceedings of this celebrated tribunal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:2
verses.text: —The Council of Tyre.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:3
verses.text: Arsenius was a bishop of the Meletian faction.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:4
verses.text: The men of his party put him in a place of concealment, and charged him to remain there as long as possible.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:5
verses.text: They then cut off the right hand of a corpse, embalmed it, placed it in a wooden case, and carried it about everywhere, declaring that it was the hand of Arsenius, who had been murdered by Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:6
verses.text: But the all-seeing eye did not permit Arsenius to remain long in concealment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:7
verses.text: He was first seen alive in Egypt; then in the Thebaid; afterwards he was led by Divine Providence to Tyre, where the hand of tragic fame was brought before the council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:8
verses.text: The friends of Athanasius hunted him up, and brought him to an inn, where they compelled him to lie hid for a time.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:9
verses.text: Early in the morning the great Athanasius came to the council.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:10
verses.text: First of all a woman of lewd life was brought in, who deposed in a loud and impudent manner that she had vowed perpetual virginity, but that Athanasius, who had lodged in her house, had violated her chastity.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:11
verses.text: After she had made her charge, the accused came forward, and with him a presbyter worthy of all praise, by name Timotheus.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:12
verses.text: The court ordered Athanasius to reply to the indictment; but he was silent, as if he had not been Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:13
verses.text: Timotheus, however, addressed her thus: "Have I, O woman, ever conversed with you, or have I entered your house?" She replied with still greater effrontery, screaming aloud in her dispute with Timotheus, and, pointing at him with her finger, exclaimed, "It was you who robbed me of my virginity; it was you who stripped me of my chastity;" adding other indelicate expressions which are used by shameless women.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:14
verses.text: The devisers of this calumny were put to shame, and all the bishops who were privy to it, blushed.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:15
verses.text: The woman was now being led out of the Court, but the great Athanasius protested that instead of sending her away they ought to examine her, and learn the name of the hatcher of the plot.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:16
verses.text: Hereupon his accusers yelled and shouted that he had perpetrated other viler crimes, of which it was utterly impossible that he could by any art or ingenuity be cleared; and that eyes, not ears, would decide on the evidence.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:17
verses.text: Having said this, they exhibited the famous box and exposed the embalmed hand to view.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:18
verses.text: At this sight all the spectators uttered a loud cry.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:19
verses.text: Some believed the accusation to be true; the others had no doubt of the falsehood, and thought that Arsenius was lurking somewhere or other in concealment.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:20
verses.text: When at length, after some difficulty, a little silence was obtained, the accused asked his judges whether any of them knew Arsenius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:21
verses.text: Several of them replying that they knew him well, Athanasius gave orders that he should be brought before them.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:22
verses.text: Then he again asked them, "Is this the right Arsenius? Is this the man I murdered? Is this the man those people mutilated after his murder by cutting off his right hand?" When they had confessed that it was the same individual, Athanasius pulled off his cloak, and exhibited two hands, both the right and the left, and said, "Let no one seek for a third hand, for man has received two hands from the Creator and no more".

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:23
verses.text: Even after this plain proof the calumniators and the judges who were privy to the crime, instead of hiding themselves, or praying that the earth might open and swallow them up, raised an uproar and commotion in the assembly, and declared that Athanasius was a sorcerer, and that he had by his magical incantations bewitched the eyes of men.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:24
verses.text: The very men who a moment before had accused him of murder now strove to tear him in pieces and to murder him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:25
verses.text: But those whom the emperor had entrusted with the preservation of order saved the life of Athanasius by dragging him away, and hurrying him on board a ship.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:26
verses.text: When he appeared before the emperor, he described all the dramatic plot which had been got up to ruin him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:27
verses.text: The calumniators sent bishops attached to their faction into Mareotis, viz.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:28
verses.text: , Theognis, bishop of Nicaea, Theodorus, bishop of Perinthus, Maris, bishop of Chalcedon, Narcissus of Cilicia, with others of the same sentiments.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:29
verses.text: Mareotis is a district near Alexandria, and derives its name from the lake Maria.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 28:30
verses.text: Here they invented other falsehoods, and, forging the reports of the trial, mixed up the charges which had been shown to be false with fresh accusations, as if they had been true, and despatched them to the emperor.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:2
verses.text: —Consecration of the Church of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:3
verses.text: —Banishment of St.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:4
verses.text: Athanasius.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:5
verses.text: All the bishops who were present at the council of Tyre, with all others from every quarter, were commanded by the emperor to proceed to aelia to consecrate the churches which he had there erected.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:6
verses.text: The emperor despatched also a number of officials of the most kindly disposition, remarkable for piety and fidelity, whom he ordered to furnish abundant supplies of provisions, not only to the bishops and their followers, but to the vast multitudes who flocked from all parts to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:7
verses.text: The holy altar was decorated with imperial hangings and with golden vessels set with gems.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:8
verses.text: When the splendid festival was concluded, each bishop returned to his own diocese.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:9
verses.text: The emperor was highly gratified when informed of the splendour and magnificence of the function, and blessed the Author of all good for having thus granted his petition.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:10
verses.text: Athanasius having complained of his unjust condemnation, the emperor commanded the bishops against whom this complaint was directed to present themselves at court.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:11
verses.text: Upon their arrival, they desisted from urging any of their former calumnies, because they knew how clearly they could be refuted; but they made it appear that Athanasius had threatened to prevent the exportation of corn.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:12
verses.text: The emperor believed what they said, and banished him to a city of Gaul called Treves.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 29:13
verses.text: This occurred in the thirtieth year of the emperor's reign.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 30:2
verses.text: —Will of the blessed Emperor Constantine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 30:3
verses.text: A year and a few months afterwards the emperor was taken ill at Nicomedia, a city of Bithynia, and, knowing the uncertainty of human life, he received the holy rite of baptism, which he had intended to have deferred until he could be baptized in the river Jordan.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 30:4
verses.text: He left as heirs of the imperial throne his three sons, Constantine, Constantius, and Constans, the youngest.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 30:5
verses.text: He ordered that the great Athanasius should return to Alexandria, and expressed this decision in the presence of Eusebius, who did all he could to dissuade him.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 31:2
verses.text: —Apology for Constantine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 31:3
verses.text: It ought not to excite astonishment that Constantine was so far deceived as to send so many great men into exile: for he believed the assertions of bishops of high fame and reputation, who skilfully concealed their malice.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 31:4
verses.text: Those who are acquainted with the Sacred Scriptures know that the holy David, although he was a prophet, was deceived; and that too not by a priest, but by one who was a menial, a slave, and a rascal.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 31:5
verses.text: I mean Ziba, who deluded the king by lies against Mephibosheth, and thus obtained his land.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 31:6
verses.text: It is not to condemn the prophet that I thus speak; but that I may defend the emperor, by showing the weakness of human nature, and to teach that credit should not be given only to those who advance accusations, even though they may appear worthy of credit; but that the other party ought also to be heard, and that one ear should be left open to the accused.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:2
verses.text: —The End of the Holy Emperor Constantine.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:3
verses.text: The emperor was now translated from his earthly dominions to a better kingdom.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:4
verses.text: The body of the emperor was enclosed in a golden coffin, and was carried to Constantinople by the governors of the provinces, the military commanders, and the other officers of state, preceded and followed by the whole army, all bitterly deploring their loss; for Constantine had been as an affectionate father to them all.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:5
verses.text: The body of the emperor was allowed to remain in the palace until the arrival of his sons, and high honours were rendered to it.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:6
verses.text: But these details require no description here, as a full account has been given by other writers.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:7
verses.text: From their works, which are easy of access, may be learnt how greatly the Ruler of all honours His faithful servants.

verses.name: Theodoret: Ecclesiastical History Book I 32:8
verses.text: If any one should be tempted to unbelief, let him look at what occurs now near the tomb and the statue of Constantine, and then he must admit the truth of what God has said in the Scriptures, "Them that honour Me I will honour, and they that despise Me shall be lightly esteemed".
